1-8B-12: APPARATUS AND EQUIPMENT; FIRE CALLS:
The council shall determine, with the advice and counsel of the fire chief, the
amount, type and size of all fire apparatus and equipment comprising the fire
department and shall purchase, repair or replace any and all fire apparatus,
equipment and accessories they deem necessary as provided by state law. In
addition:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The council shall designate and provide safe and convenient housing for
all fire apparatus and equipment.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The council shall establish suitable arrangements for notifying all
members of the department of alarms of fire, and it is incumbent upon members
to arrange for forwarding alarms to themselves when they are called away from
home or their place of business.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â No person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment of the city for any
private purpose; nor shall said apparatus or equipment be used by any other
department of the city without express permission from the fire chief; nor
shall any person wilfully and without proper authority take away or conceal any
article used in any way by the fire department.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Calls for fire aid from neighboring communities necessitating any
response of fire apparatus or manpower of the department must have the consent
of the mayor or the fire chief or, in case neither can be contacted, the next
subordinate officer of the department, before response may be made beyond the
department's jurisdiction.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The mayor is hereby authorized, with the approval of the council, to
enter into agreements with contiguous fire protection districts, properly
formed under state law, and adjacent municipalities; provided, such agreements
shall specify that the officer in charge of the fire department shall have the
authority to refuse response to such calls if, in his judgment, the absence of
fire apparatus would unduly endanger the protection of the city. (Ord. 13-O-15,
6-18-2013)
1-8B-13: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
The following general provisions shall apply to the operation of the fire
department:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Badge: The city shall furnish every member of the department with a
badge designating his rank in the department.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Right Of Way Of Vehicles: City fire apparatus shall have the right of
way over all other vehicular and pedestrian traffic only when responding to an
alarm of fire or other emergency call. Fire apparatus may, at that time,
properly disregard traffic control signs and signals; provided, due precaution
is taken by reducing speed, by continuously operating sirens and signal lights,
and using all other safety precautions. When returning to the station after a
fire response, all traffic signs and signals shall be obeyed.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Driving Over Fire Hose: No person shall drive any vehicle over hose
laid at a fire where the hose is in use, except by permission of the fire
officer in charge.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Parking Near Facilities; Following Apparatus: No person shall park any
vehicle or cause any obstruction within fifteen feet (15') of the driveway
entrance to any fire station, or within ten feet (10') of any fire hydrant, nor
shall the driver of any vehicle, except cars of members of the fire department,
follow within three hundred feet (300') of any fire apparatus responding to an
alarm of fire, nor park within the block where the fire apparatus has stopped
at a fire.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Interference With, Refusal To Aid Fire Department Personnel: No person
shall interfere with a firefighter in the performance of his duty, nor shall
said person refuse or neglect to furnish any member of the fire department any
help or information he may possess as to the cause or origin of any fire, or
hinder any fire investigation in any manner.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â False Alarms: No person shall turn in, or cause to be turned in, any
false alarm of fire. (Ord. 13-O-15, 6-18-2013)
1-8B-14: VIOLATIONS; ENFORCEMENT:
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to the general penalty provided by
this code. In addition:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All members of the fire department are hereby given the necessary
police powers for enforcing this article applying at the scene of a fire.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any member of the department violating the rules and regulations of the
department or who is guilty of the charges preferred against him before the
fire and police commission may be fined, suspended for a specified time without
pay, or discharged from the department as the commission shall determine and
direct. (Ord. 13-O-15, 6-18-2013)
1-8B-15: FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND AND BOARD:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Pension Fund:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Fund Created: There is hereby created a firefighters' pension fund
which is hereby declared to be adopted and in full force and effect in the
city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Financing Fund: The following monies and appropriations shall be set
apart and constitute the firefighters' pension fund: (Ord., 4-25-1951; amd.
Ord. 13-O-15, 6-18-2013)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â An amount determined by the pension authority of the state
deducted from the salaries of the active firefighters. (1991 Code; amd. Ord.
13-O-15, 6-18-2013)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â All rewards given or paid to members of the fire department.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The council shall annually hereafter levy a tax upon all the
taxable property at the rate on the dollar on all such taxable property which
will produce an amount which, when added to the deductions of the salaries and
wages of firefighters and receipts available from all other sources as
hereinafter referred to, will equal a sufficient sum to meet the annual
requirements of the pension fund under the provisions of this article. Such tax
shall be levied and collected in a like manner with general taxes, and shall be
in addition to all other taxes now or hereafter authorized to be levied upon
all property and shall be in addition to the amount authorized to be levied for
general purposes as provided by state law, provided, the council may dispense
with the levy of such tax if the pension fund, over and above the reserve fund,
is sufficient to meet all demands of those requiring payment from the pension
fund.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Gifts To Fund: The board of trustees may take, by gift, devise or
bequest, any money, real estate and personal property, and such money, real
estate and personal property so obtained shall be paid into said pension fund
and treated as a part thereof. (Ord., 4-25-1951; amd. Ord. 13-O-15, 6-18-2013)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Board Of Trustees Of Fund:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Board Created; Composition: There is hereby created a board of
trustees of the firefighters' pension fund which shall consist of the following
members:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Two (2) members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Two (2) active participants of the pension fund who are elected
from the active participants of the fund; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â One retired person retired under the firemen's pension fund act
of 1919 who is elected from persons retired under the firemen's pension fund
act.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â For the purposes of this section, a firefighter receiving a
disability pension shall be considered a retired firefighter. In the event that
there are no retired firefighters under the fund or if none is willing to serve
on the board, then an additional active firefighter shall be elected to the
board in lieu of the retired firefighter that would otherwise be elected.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Each member of the board so elected shall hold office for a term
of three (3) years and until his or her successor has been duly elected and
qualified. The board shall canvass the ballots and declare which persons have
been elected and for what term or terms respectively. In case of a tie vote
between two (2) or more candidates, the board shall determine by lot which
candidate or candidates have been elected and for what term or terms
respectively.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â In the event of the failure, resignation, or inability to act of
any board member, a successor shall be elected for the unexpired term at a
special election called by the board and conducted in the same manner as a
regular election.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â The board shall elect annually from its members a president and
secretary.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â h.Â Â Â Board members shall not receive or have any right to receive any
salary from a pension fund for services performed as board members.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Duties: The powers and duties of the board of trustees shall be in
accordance with the provisions of state statute governing the same. (Ord. 07-O-
57, 10-15-2007; amd. Ord. 13-O-15, 6-18-2013)
1-8B-16: RAPID ENTRY SYSTEM KEY BOXES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Required:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The owner or person in control of the following types of buildings
shall install and maintain a fire department rapid entry key lock box of a type
approved by the fire chief:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â A structure which contains a fire alarm that uses an automatic
dialer or contains an automatic fire suppression system.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Multi-family residential structures, with four (4) or more units,
including senior apartment/condo complexes that have restricted access to the
living units.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Commercial and industrial buildings identified by fire officials
as difficult to access during emergencies.
Note: Any building or structure having on site twenty four (24) hour security
personnel may be exempt from the requirement of this section at the discretion
of the fire department.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Persons or entities who own existing buildings or structures which
are subject to the requirements of this section shall have two (2) years from
the effective date hereof to comply with the requirements. Persons or entities
who construct buildings or structures which would be subject to the
requirements of this section shall comply with the requirements at the time of
construction.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Keys Required And Installation: The owner or person in control of
buildings or facilities described in subsection A of this section required to
have a fire department rapid entry key lock box shall cause to be placed in
such lock box a key to the following areas:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The owner is responsible for ordering and installing the knox box.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The fire chief shall designate the type of key lock system to be
implemented.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The lock box shall be installed on the front of the building near
the main entry door, on the right hand side, between six (6) and eight feet
(8') above the ground, unless approved at a higher or lower level, by the
building department or fire department. The fire department may wish to locate
in an alternate site in some cases. The owner should contact the fire
department prior to mounting the knox box to ensure proper location.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The lock box shall contain the key(s) for the exterior doors, the
keys for all interior doors within the building which control access to shared
systems (HVAC, alarm panels, sprinkler controls and electrical panels). The
keys should be labeled and easily identified.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Access To Fire Department Rapid Entry Key Lock Box: The owner or person
in control of any building or facility described in subsection A of this
section required to have a fire department rapid entry key lock box shall be
present, himself or through his agent, during access to such lock box by the
fire department except when the fire department has responded to an emergency
at the property.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Rules And Regulations: The fire chief may establish rules and
regulations for the placement and maintenance of fire department rapid entry
key lock boxes within the city, including, but not limited to, the
specification of approved types of fire department rapid entry key lock boxes.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Update Of Keys And Information: The owner or person in control of any
building or facility described in subsection A of this section required to have
a fire department rapid entry key lock box shall provide keys capable of access
from such lock box at all times to the fire department.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Limitation Of Liability: The city assumes no liability for any of the
following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Any defects in the operation of the fire department rapid entry key
lock box, of any of the keys contained within such lock box or any information
stored within the lock box or otherwise provided to the city;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The failure or neglect of any owner or person in control of a
building or facility required to have a fire department rapid entry key lock
box to provide access to the lock box; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The security of any property required to have a fire department
rapid entry key lockbox due to access to the lockbox by any person. (Ord. 09-O-
1, 1-20-2009; amd. Ord. 13-O-15, 6-18-2013)
1-8B-17: HAZARDOUS MATERIALS; COST AND PENALTIES:
Any person responsible for or liable for any remedial action, removal, release
or threatened release of hazardous material shall reimburse the city of
Charleston for costs and charges incurred in connection with any such remedial
action, removal, release or threatened release of hazardous material emergency
action for removal, remedial action within sixty (60) days after such action is
rendered by the city of Charleston or any other agency rendering mutual aid.
Minimum charges for such remedial action, removal, release or threatened
release of hazardous material shall be as follows:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The reasonable cost of each vehicle responding as determined by the
responding agency, but in no case less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per
hour per vehicle; and
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The cost of all personnel, including any overtime cost to the city of
Charleston or to any responding agency incurred as a result of remedial action,
removal, release or threatened release of hazardous material, or any mitigation
or containment operations; and
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The cost of all materials and equipment used, expended, depleted,
destroyed or removed from service in accordance with federal, state or local
law, regulations or ordinances as a result of the remedial action, removal,
release or threatened release of hazardous material, or any mitigation or
containment operations.
Any person liable for the release or threatened release of a hazardous material
who fails without sufficient cause to pay for or provide removal or remedial
action upon or in accordance with a notice and request of the city of
Charleston, or in accordance with any order of any court having jurisdiction on
the matter, shall be liable to the city of Charleston for any cost incurred by
the city of Charleston as a result of such failure to provide or take such
removal or remedial action, together with the cost of any removal or remedial
action taken by the city of Charleston in accordance with this section, and for
any and all attorney fees and related costs incurred in connection therewith.
In addition, any such person who negligently violates this section shall be
fined not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed for each day on which a violation occurs or
continues to occur. (Ord. 10-O-1, 2-16-2010; amd. Ord. 13-O-15, 6-18-2013)
1-8B-18: FIREFIGHTER SERVICES OUTSIDE CORPORATE LIMITS:
Any persons, businesses, and other entities that are not residents of the city
of Charleston or whose property is located outside of the corporate limits are
liable to the city for any firefighting service fees rendered to them or their
property in an amount not exceeding the actual cost of the service for all
firefighting services rendered by the city of Charleston. Such persons,
businesses and other entities shall reimburse the city of Charleston for costs
and charges incurred in connection with any such firefighting services within
sixty (60) days of being invoiced for same. The base rates applicable to all
calls for firefighter services to nonresidents of the city and those properties
located outside of the corporate limits may not exceed the reasonable cost of
providing those services and may not, in any event, exceed two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) per hour per vehicle, plus seventy dollars ($70.00) per hour
per firefighter. The time shall be computed from initial alarm through to
return to station or other formal clearance of the call. No charge shall be
made for services for which the total charge would be less than fifty dollars
($50.00).
An additional charge may be levied to reimburse the city of Charleston for
extraordinary expenses of materials used in rendering the services. Nothing in
this section shall impact any agreement entered into by the city of Charleston
and persons, businesses, and other entities that are nonresidents of the
municipality. This section shall not impact services rendered through mutual
aid, which shall be determined by the fire chief. Nonresidents will be charged
at the discretion of the fire chief. Nothing in this section shall require the
city of Charleston to supply any firefighting services to property located
outside the corporate limits of the municipality. (Ord. 16-O-22, 6-7-2016)
1-8B-19: REIMBURSEMENT FOR SPECIALIZED RESCUE SERVICES:
Any person responsible for or liable for any specialized rescue services
provided by the city of Charleston fire department shall reimburse the city of
Charleston for reasonable costs and charges incurred in connection with any
such specialized rescue services within sixty (60) days after such action is
rendered by the city of Charleston or any other agency rendering mutual aid.
The total amount collected may not exceed the reasonable cost of providing
those specialized rescue services and may not, in any event, exceed one hundred
twenty five dollars ($125.00) per hour per vehicle and thirty five dollars
($35.00) per hour per firefighter. The fee may be charged to any of the
following parties:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The owner of the property on which the specialized rescue services
occurred;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any person involved in an activity that caused or contributed to the
emergency;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â An individual who is rescued during the emergency and his or her
employer if the person was acting in furtherance of the employer's interests;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â In cases involving the recovery of property, any person having control
or custody of the property at the time of the emergency.
For the purposes of this section, the term "specialized rescue services"
includes, but is not limited to, structural collapse, tactical rescue, high
angle rescue, underwater rescue and recovery, confined space rescue, below
grade rescue, and trench rescue. (Ord. 16-O-22, 6-7-2016)

1-8D-3: CITY PLANNER:

ARTICLE H. ADMINISTRATIVE CODE HEARING DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-8H-1: Purpose
1-8H-2: Definitions

1-8H-13: Lessor Of Vehicle; Liability

1-8H-16: Building Code Violations
1-8H-17: Penalties
1-8H-18: Settlement Of Violations
1-8H-19: Severability
1-8H-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this article is to provide for a fair and efficient system of
enforcement of City ordinances as may be allowed by law and directed by
ordinance, through the administrative adjudication of violations of such City
ordinances and by establishing a schedule of fines and penalties, and authority
and procedures for collection of unpaid fines and penalties. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-
7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the words described below shall have the
meanings ascribed to them herein unless the context in which such terms are
used requires otherwise.
BUILDING CODE: Any City ordinance, law, Housing or Building Code or zoning
ordinance that establishes construction, plumbing, heating, electrical, fire
prevention, sanitation or other health and safety standards that are applicable
to structures within the geographical limits of the City of Charleston or any
City ordinance that requires, after notice, the cutting of weeds, the removal
of garbage and debris, the removal of inoperable motor vehicles, or the
abatement of nuisances from private property.
CITY OFFICIAL: All full time police officers as well as any other officer,
agent, or employee of the City of Charleston authorized to enforce the City
Code.
CODE: Any City ordinance, law, rule, regulation or code, except such ordinances
for which the potential penalty described therein includes a period of
incarceration, any offense under the Illinois Vehicle Code or a similar offense
that is a traffic regulation governing the movement of vehicles, and any
reportable offense under section 6-204 of the Illinois Vehicle Code.
COMPLAINT: A formal written accusation against a person or entity such as a
ticket or notice of violation for a violation of the City Code.
DEFAULT: A failure to appear for a scheduled hearing or legal proceeding.
EMERGENCY SITUATIONS: Those situations that reasonably constitute threats to
the public interests, safety or welfare.
HEARING OFFICER: A person appointed by the Mayor with the advice of, and
consent of, the City Council to preside over administrative hearings, as set
forth in this article.
NONEMERGENCY SITUATION: Any situation that does not reasonably constitute a
threat to the public interests, safety or welfare.
OWNER: A. For the purpose of a violation relating to real property, the person
to whom the County Collector sent the last ascertainable tax bill; and
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â For the purpose of a violation relating to motor vehicles, the person
to whom the motor vehicle is registered, as provided by the records of the
Secretary of State of Illinois. Any person so described herein may present
clear and convincing evidence to overcome the presumption that such person is
the owner of the property and/or motor vehicle for which the person received a
notice of violation.
PETITIONER: The person or entity making a City Code violation allegation
initiating the administrative adjudication hearing process.
PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE: The bare minimum of evidence needed to bring a case
before a hearing officer.
RESPONDENT: A person or entity who is accused of a violation. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-
7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-3: NONEXCLUSIVITY:
The provisions of this article shall not preclude the City from using other
methods or proceedings to enforce the City Code, including, but not limited to,
the institution of any action in the Circuit Court of Coles County, Illinois,
or any administrative proceeding. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26,
7-5-2017)
1-8H-4: CODE HEARING DEPARTMENT; ESTABLISHMENT; JURISDICTION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2.2-1 et seq., "Code Hearing
Departments", 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., "Building Code Violations" and 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3 "Administrative Adjudication of Violations of
Traffic Regulations Concerning the Standing, Parking or Condition of Vehicles",
as from time to time amended, are hereby adopted in their entirety and any
person charged with the violation of a Municipal ordinance may be prosecuted
under and in accordance with the provisions herein.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â There is hereby established a Code Hearing Department as an independent
agency of the City, which is authorized to provide for and operate a system of
administrative adjudication, as more fully described herein, which shall have
jurisdiction over the adjudication and enforcement of any violation of the City
Code, including, but not limited to, parking and vehicle registration
violations, Housing, Building and Zoning Code violations, and engineering and
health safety violations, but excluding ordinances for which the potential
penalty described therein includes a period of incarceration, any offense under
the Illinois Vehicle Code or a similar offense that is a traffic regulation
governing the movement of vehicles, and any reportable offense under section 6-
204 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26,
7-5-2017)
1-8H-5: CODE HEARING DEPARTMENT; ORGANIZATION:
The Code Hearing Department shall be comprised of a Hearing Officer, a Code
Administrator, any designated member of law enforcement, and any other duly
appointed person or persons deemed necessary for the efficient administration
of the Code Hearing Department, with the following powers and authority:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Hearing Officer: All adjudicatory hearings shall be presided over by a
Hearing Officer.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Prior to conducting administrative adjudication hearings, the
Hearing Officer shall have successfully completed a formal training program
which includes the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Instruction on the rules of procedure of the administrative
adjudication hearings that they will conduct and preside over;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Orientation to each subject area of the Code for which they may
adjudicate a violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Observation of administrative adjudication hearings; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Participation in hypothetical cases, including ruling on evidence
and issuing final orders.
In addition a Hearing Officer must be an attorney licensed to practice law in
the State of Illinois for at least three (3) years. A Hearing Officer may not
be an inspector or law enforcement officer employed by the City.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Hearing Officers are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the
existence of an ordinance violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant
testimony or tangible items at an administrative adjudication hearing, upon the
request of the parties or their representatives;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Preserve and authenticate the record of the administrative
adjudication hearings, including all exhibits and evidence introduced at the
hearing;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Issue a determination, based on the evidence presented at the
administrative adjudication hearing, of whether a Code violation occurred or
exists. The Hearing Officer's determination shall be in writing and shall
include written findings of fact and law, a decision, and an order including
the fine, penalty or other action with which the respondent must comply. The
findings, decision and order must allow a reviewing court to determine whether
the decision of the Hearing Officer was arbitrary and capricious; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Impose penalties consistent with the applicable Code provisions
and assess costs upon finding a party liable for the charged violation. The
Hearing Officer shall have the authority to increase or decrease the fines set
forth in the Code where evidence of aggravating or mitigating circumstances is
presented. In no event shall the Hearing Officer have authority to: 1) impose a
penalty of incarceration, or 2) impose a fine in excess of seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). The maximum monetary fine under this subsection A2e shall be
exclusive of costs of enforcement or costs incurred by the City to secure
compliance with the Code and shall not be applicable to cases to enforce the
collection of any tax imposed and collected by the City.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Code Administrator: The Code Administrator shall either be an employee
of the City appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the City
Council, or an independent contractor or agency contracted by the City to
perform such duties as enumerated herein. The Code Administrator is hereby
authorized, empowered and directed to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Operate and manage the system of administrative adjudication of all
Code violations as may be permitted by law and directed by ordinance;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Adopt, distribute and process all notices as may be required under
this article or as may reasonably be required to carry out the purpose of this
article;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Collect monies paid as fines and/or penalties assessed after a final
determination of liability or to coordinate with the Finance Department for
such purpose;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Certify copies of final determinations of all Code violations
adjudicated pursuant to this article, and any factual reports verifying the
final determination of any violation which were issued in accordance with this
article or the laws of the State of Illinois, including 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-208.3 (standing, parking or conditions of vehicles) as from time
to time amended;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Certify reports to the Secretary of State concerning initiation of
suspension of driving privileges in accordance with the provisions of this
article and those of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5 (failure to pay
fines - suspension);
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Promulgate rules and regulations reasonably necessary for the
efficient operation and maintenance of the system of administrative
adjudication hereby established; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Collect unpaid fines and penalties through private collection
agencies that may be retained by the City or by requesting the City Attorney to
act on behalf of the City in filing complaints in the Coles County Circuit
Court, seeking judgments for unpaid fines or penalties and pursuing all
postjudgment remedies available under current law.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Automation: The Code Administrator is hereby further authorized,
empowered and directed to operate and maintain a computer program for the
system of administrative adjudication hereby established, on a day to day
basis, including, but not limited to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Inputting of violation notice information;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Establishing hearing dates and notice dates;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Recording fine and penalty assessment and payments;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Issuing payment receipts;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Issuing succeeding notice of hearing dates and/or final
determinations of liability, issuing notices of impending immobilization,
issuing notices of impoundment, and issuing notices of impending driver's
license suspension as may be required, in accordance with the Illinois Vehicle
Code. Nothing in this section is intended to preclude the Code Administrator
from including one (1) or more of the above notices in the same notice report;
and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Keeping accurate records of appearances and nonappearances at
administrative adjudication hearing, pleas entered and fines and other
penalties assessed and paid.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Security: The City may choose to provide security for administrative
adjudication hearings, in order to maintain hearing room decorum and perform

Hearing Officer or the Code Administrator. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord.
17-O-26, 7-5-2017)

1-8H-7: COMMENCEMENT OF HEARINGS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Institution Of A Hearing: A proceeding before a Hearing Officer shall
be instituted upon the filing with the Code Administrator of a written sworn
pleading, violation notice, complaint or citation by any authorized official of
the City, including law enforcement officers, Code Enforcement Officers, and
such other employees as authorized.
In the event a complaint causing the initiation of a hearing is filed by a
tenant or occupant of a dwelling who is not also the owner thereof, no action
for eviction, abatement of a nuisance, forcible entry and detainer or other
similar proceeding, whether it be civil or criminal, shall be threatened or
instituted against such tenant or occupant solely because such tenant or
occupant files such complaint or agrees to testify or present tangible evidence
at an administrative adjudication hearing. The foregoing sentence shall not
apply if the owner proves by a preponderance of the evidence that such tenant
or occupant is the proximate cause of the violation for which the hearing is
commenced.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Service Of Notice Of Hearing: Respondents shall be served with a copy
of the written sworn pleading, violation notice, complaint or citation along
with a notice of hearing in a manner reasonably calculated to give them actual
notice of the proceeding instituted against them, by one (1) of the following
means:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Personal service upon a party or its authorized agent;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Service by certified mail, return receipt requested, at the party's
last known address;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Service by first class mail, postage prepaid, at the party's last
known address; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â If the party's last known address cannot be ascertained after a
diligent search, by posting a copy of the sworn pleading, complaint or citation
in a conspicuous place upon the property or motor vehicle where the violation
is found when the party is the owner of the property or motor vehicle; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Any notice presented by first class or certified mail, or by
posting, shall be deemed served three (3) days after the deposit of such notice
in the U.S. mail or the posting of such notice.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Contents Of Notice Of Hearing: Notices of hearing shall include:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The name and address of the party alleged to have violated the
ordinance, if known;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The date, time and place of the violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The type and nature of the ordinance violation to be adjudicated,
including a reference to the appropriate section of the Code, and the potential
fines which may result from a finding of liability. And, with respect to Code
violations related to the standing, parking or condition of a vehicle, a
summary of the information contained on the citation as set forth in subsection
1-8H-11B of this article;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Vehicle make and state registration number;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â With respect to Code violations related to the standing, parking or
condition of a vehicle, the means by which the respondent may waive the right
to a hearing and pay the applicable fine for the alleged violation, and that
payment of the indicated fine, and of any applicable penalty for late payment,
shall operate as a final disposition of the violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â A section entitled, "Notice of Hearing" which shall clearly set
forth that the person receiving a notice of ordinance violation may appear at
an administrative adjudicatory hearing to contest the validity of the violation
notice on the date and at the time and place as specified in the notice of
hearing;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â The date, time and location of the administrative adjudicatory
hearing, if applicable, which hearing date shall not be less than thirty (30)
nor more than forty (40) days after the date of the complaint in nonemergency
situations. In emergency situations the hearing date shall not be less than
three (3) nor more than seven (7) days after the date of the complaint;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â The fine and penalty for the violation of the ordinance, if
applicable, the administrative hearing fee, and the fine and any penalty which
may be assessed for late payment;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â The legal authority and jurisdiction under which the hearing is to
be held;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â Statement that the penalties for a failure to appear at the hearing
will result in a default judgment being entered against the respondent and a
final determination of liability for the cited violation and penalties
indicated as well as costs of the administrative hearing as provided for;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â Statement that upon the occurrence of a final determination of
liability for the failure, and the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust,
available administrative or judicial procedures for review, any unpaid fine or
penalty will constitute a debt due and owing the City with the judgment being
enforceable at the Circuit Court. In addition, a statement with respect to Code
violations related to the standing, parking or condition of a vehicle, the
notices shall state that vehicle immobilization and driver's license suspension
may be imposed if fines and penalties are not paid in full;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 12.Â Â Â The signature and identification of the person issuing the sworn
pleading, violation notice, complaint or citation, which signature shall act as
a certification of the accuracy of all information contained within the
complaint;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 13.Â Â Â In the case of a notice produced by a computer device, the person
issuing the sworn pleading, violation notice, complaint or citation shall sign
an affidavit attesting to the correctness of all violation notices and
complaints produced by the device while under his/her control;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 14.Â Â Â Any witnesses or complainants who may be called to testify for the
City who are not employees or officers thereof; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 15.Â Â Â Statement setting forth applicability of and providing for payment
and waiver of an administrative adjudicatory hearing.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Scheduling And Docketing Of Hearings: Administrative adjudication
hearings shall be scheduled and docketed by the Code Administrator not less
than thirty (30) nor more than forty (40) days after the notice of hearing is
served on the respondent in nonemergency situations. In emergency situations
the hearing date shall not be less than three (3) nor more than seven (7) days
after the date the notice of hearing is served on the respondent. (Ord. 16-O-
23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-8: HEARING PROCEDURES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Rights: Parties shall be provided with an opportunity for a hearing
before or during which they may exercise any or all of the following rights:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Be represented by counsel, at their own expense. Respondents shall
not be entitled to have an attorney appointed to represent them;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Present and cross examine witnesses; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Request the Hearing Officer to issue subpoenas to direct the
attendance and testimony of relevant witnesses or the production of relevant
tangible evidence.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Rules Of Evidence Shall Not Govern: The formal and technical rules of
evidence shall not apply in an administrative adjudication hearing authorized
under this article. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted only if it is
the type commonly relied upon by reasonable prudent persons in the conduct of
their affairs.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Standard Of Proof: Administrative adjudication hearings are civil in
nature. The City shall bear the standard of proof to prove by a preponderance
of the evidence the occurrence or existence of a violation of the Code. A
sworn, written pleading, complaint or citation shall constitute a prima facie
evidence of the violation.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Recording: All administrative adjudication hearings conducted pursuant
to this article shall be recorded.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Defenses: It shall be a defense to a Code violation charged under this
article if the owner, his attorney, or any other agent or representative proves
by a preponderance of the evidence that:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The Code violation alleged in the notice did not in fact exist at
the time of the citation, pleading or complaint; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The Code violation alleged in the notice occurred before the owner
became the owner of the real or personal property. Notwithstanding the
foregoing sentence, any existing order to correct a Code violation and/or
sanctions imposed by the City as a result of a finding of a Code violation
under this article shall attach to the property as well as to the owner of the
property, so that a finding of a Code violation against one owner cannot be
avoided by conveying or transferring the property to another owner. Any
subsequent transferee or owner of the property takes the same subject to the
findings, decision and order of a Hearing Officer under this article.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Continuances: No continuances shall be authorized by a Hearing Officer
for any administrative adjudication hearing commenced under this article except
in cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of
the respondent or owner. Any continuance authorized by the Hearing Officer
shall not exceed twenty five (25) days. Lack of preparation shall not be
grounds for a continuance.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Default: If on the date set for hearing the respondent or his/her
attorney fails to appear, the Hearing Officer may find the respondent in
default and shall proceed.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Contents Of Final Determination Of Liability: A final determination of
liability as determined by the Hearing Officer shall be provided to the parties
following the conclusion of an administrative hearing by personally providing
such or, in the case of a default judgment, by mailing within five (5) business
days of the date the order is issued and shall contain, but not be limited to,
the following information and warnings:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A decision and order stating whether a Code violation exists;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A statement of any penalties or sanctions imposed which penalties or
sanctions debts are due and owing the City;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A statement of any finding of costs imposed if a Code violation is
found to exist, which costs shall be debts due and owing the City;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â A statement of any sanctions imposed including, but not limited to,
orders to abate, injunctions, orders to cease and desist, orders to perform
community service and other appropriate orders as determined by the Hearing
Officer;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â A warning that failure to comply with any orders to abate, cease and
desist, perform community service or other appropriate order and/or pay the
fine and any penalty due and owing the City within the time specified may
result in proceeding with collection and enforcement procedures in the same
manner as a judgment entered by any court of competent jurisdiction; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Any other warning of possible impoundment as permitted by law or
ordinance.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Final Determination Of Liability: A final determination of liability
shall occur following the failure to pay the fine or penalty or comply with
other imposed sanctions after the Hearing Officer's determination of liability
and the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, any administrative review
procedures hereinafter set forth. Where a person fails to appear at the
administrative hearing to contest the alleged violation on the date and at the
time and place specified in a prior served or mailed notice, the Hearing
Officer's determination of liability shall become final either upon a denial of
a timely petition to set aside that determination or upon the expiration of the
period for filing a petition without a filing having been made. Failure by any
respondent to pay or mail payment of the fine for any violation of this City
Code within thirty five (35) days of the issuance of the final determination of
liability will automatically subject the respondent to a penalty for late
payment. The penalty for late payment shall be the amount set forth in section
1-8H-17, "Penalties", of this article. Failure to pay or mail payment of the
fine may result in the fine being referred to a collection agency and will
automatically subject the respondent to an additional administrative fee of
twenty five dollars ($25.00).
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Judicial Review: Any final decision by a Hearing Officer that a Code
violation does or does not exist shall constitute a final determination for
purposes of judicial review and shall be subject to review under the Illinois
Administrative Review Law, 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq., or
as hereinafter amended. Any person filing for judicial review under the
Administrative Review Law shall be subject to the assessment costs for the
preparation and certification of the record of proceedings before the Hearing
Officer. Such cost shall be assessed as one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the
first page of the transcript and twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each page
thereafter. Any failure to pay such fee shall subject the party seeking review
to the provisions of 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-109, including
dismissal of the complaint on motion of the City. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd.
Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-9: ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any final decision by a Hearing Officer that a Code violation does or
does not exist shall constitute a final determination for purposes of judicial
review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law. The findings, decision and
order of the Hearing Officer shall constitute a final determination for
purposes of judicial review and shall be subject to a review in the Circuit
Court of Coles County, Illinois, and the provisions of the Administrative
Review Law and all amendments and modifications thereto, and the rules adopted
pursuant thereto are adopted and shall apply to and govern every action for the
judicial review of the final findings, decision and order of a Hearing Officer
under this article. The plaintiff in the administrative review proceeding shall
pay to the City of Charleston the costs of preparing and certifying the record
of proceedings before the Hearing Officer. The failure to make that payment
shall relieve the City of the necessity of filing the answer required by 735
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-108 (Illinois Administrative Review Law) and
shall be authority for the entry of an order by the court, on motion thereof by
the City or any other respondent, dismissing the complaint. Any fine, other
sanction or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other sanction or cost imposed,
remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of or the failure to exhaust judicial
review procedures under the Illinois Administrative Review Law are a debt due
and owing the City and may be collected in accordance with applicable law.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Failure of the respondent to pay such fine or penalty after the
exhaustion of or the failure to exhaust judicial review procedures under the
Illinois Administrative Review Law may result in the City filing a petition in
the Circuit Court of Coles County to have reduced to judgment any unpaid fine
or penalty with costs, and, if applicable: 1) the immobilization of the
person's vehicle for failure to pay fines or penalties for five (5) or more
parking violations and 2) the suspension of the person's driver's license for
failure to pay fines or penalties for ten (10) or more parking violations.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Nothing in this section shall prevent the City of Charleston from
consolidating multiple findings, decisions and orders against a person in such
a proceeding.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Upon commencement of an action to enforce, the City shall file a
certified copy of the findings, decision and order, which shall be accompanied
by a certification that recites facts sufficient to show that the findings,
decision and order, was issued in accordance with this Code. Service of the
summons and a copy of the petition may be by any method provided by the Code of
Civil Procedure or by certified mail, return receipt requested. If the court is
satisfied that the findings, decision and order were entered in accordance with
the requirements of this section and the applicable ordinance and that the
respondent had an opportunity for a hearing and for judicial review as provided
for herein: 1) the court shall render a judgment in favor of the City and
against the respondent for the relief indicated in the findings, decision and
order, plus costs. Such judgment shall have the same effect and may be enforced
in the same manner as other judgments for the recovery of money; and 2) the
court may also issue such other orders and injunction as are requested by the
City to enforce the order of the Hearing Officer. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd.
Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-10: ALTERNATIVE ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In place of a proceeding under section
1-8H-9 of this article, after expiration of the period in which judicial review
under the Illinois Administrative Review Law may be sought for a final
determination of a Code violation other than a Building Code violation, unless
stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, the findings, decision, and order
of the Hearing Officer may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered
by a court of competent jurisdiction.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In any case in which a respondent has failed to comply with a judgment
ordering a respondent to correct a Code violation other than a Building Code
violation, or imposing any fine or other sanction as a result of a Code
violation other than a Building Code violation, any expenses incurred by the
City to enforce the judgment, including, but not limited to, attorney fees,
court costs, and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure, after
they are fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction or a Hearing Officer, shall
be a debt due and owing the City and may be collected in accordance with
applicable law. Prior to any expenses being fixed by a Hearing Officer pursuant
to this subsection, the City shall provide notice to the respondent that states
that the respondent shall appear at a hearing before the Administrative Hearing
Officer to determine whether the respondent has failed to comply with the
judgment. The notice shall set the date for such a hearing, which shall not be
less than seven (7) days from the date that notice is served. If notice is
served by mail, the seven (7) day period shall begin to run on the date that
the notice was deposited in the mail.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Upon being recorded in the manner required by article XII of the Code
of Civil Procedure or by the Uniform Commercial Code, a lien shall be imposed
on the real estate or personal estate, or both, of the respondent in the amount
of any debt due and owing the Municipality under this section. The lien may be
enforced in the same manner as a judgment lien pursuant to a judgment of a
court of competent jurisdiction.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â A Hearing Officer may set aside any judgment entered by default and set
a new hearing date, upon a petition filed within twenty one (21) days after the
issuance of the order of default, if the Hearing Officer determines that the
petitioner's failure to appear at the hearing was for good cause or at any time
if the petitioner establishes that the City did not provide proper service of
process. If any judgment is set aside pursuant to this section, the Hearing
Officer shall have authority to enter an order extinguishing any lien which has
been recorded for any debt due and owing the City as a result of the vacated
default judgment. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-11: MOTOR VEHICLE VIOLATIONS; CITATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation of any provision of the
Code prohibiting or restricting vehicular parking, stopping or standing, the
owner shall be prima facie responsible for the violation and subject to the
penalty thereof.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation of any provision of the
Code prohibiting or restricting vehicular parking, stopping or standing, any
law enforcement officer, traffic control aide, other designated member of law
enforcement, parking enforcement aide or other person designated by the Code
Administrator observing such violation may issue a parking violation notice,
and serve the notice on the owner of the vehicle by handing it to the operator
of the vehicle, if he is present, or by affixing it to the vehicle in a
conspicuous place. The issuer of the notice shall specify on the notice his
identification number, the particular parking regulation allegedly violated,
the make and state registration number of the cited vehicle, and the place,
date and time and nature of the alleged violation and shall certify the
correctness of the specified information by signing his name as provided in
section 11-208.3 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-208.3, as amended. The foregoing shall not relieve the Code Administrator
from the duties set forth in section
1-8H-7 of this article with respect to scheduling a hearing on such alleged
violation and providing notice thereof.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the owner of the
vehicle or his designee, to remove from a vehicle a parking violation notice
affixed pursuant to this article.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The Code Administrator shall distribute parking violation notices to
parking enforcement aides, other persons authorized to issue parking violation
notices, and law enforcement for issuance pursuant to these provisions. All
parking enforcement aides, other persons authorized to issue parking violation
notices, and law enforcement must retain a receipt for every notice issued.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The Code Administrator shall compile and maintain complete and accurate
records relating to all parking violation notices issued and the dispositions
thereof, whether by payment of the fine or by final determination of the
Hearing Officer. In addition, the Code Administrator shall make certified
reports to the Secretary of State pursuant to section 6-306.5 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-12: DETERMINATION OF LIABILITY; MOTOR VEHICLE CITATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Final Determination: Where a respondent either fails to pay the
indicated fine prior to the hearing or fails to appear at a hearing, a final
determination of parking violation liability shall be entered in the amount of
the fine indicated on the notice of violation. Failure to pay the fine within
thirty five (35) business days of a final determination of parking violation
liability will result in the imposition of a late payment penalty pursuant to
subsection B of this section. Upon the occurrence of a final determination of
parking violation liability and after expiration of the period in which
judicial review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law may be sought any
unpaid fine or penalty will constitute a debt due and owing the City.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Late Payment: Failure by any respondent to pay or mail payment of the
fine for a parking violation within thirty five (35) days of the issuance of
the final determination of liability will automatically subject the respondent
to a penalty for late payment. The penalty for late payment shall be the amount
set forth in section
1-8H-17, "Penalties", of this article. Failure to pay or mail payment of the
fine after a sixty (60) day period commencing on the issuance of the final
determination of liability will result in the fine being referred to a
collection agency and will automatically subject the respondent to an
additional administrative fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00).
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Defenses: A person charged with a parking violation may contest the
charge through an administrative adjudication hearing limited to one (1) or
more of the following grounds with appropriate evidence to support:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â That the respondent was not the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle
at the time of the violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â That the cited vehicle or its state registration plates were stolen
at the time the violation occurred;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â That the relevant signs prohibiting or restricting parking, if
necessary, were missing or obscured;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â That the relevant parking meter was inoperable or malfunctioned
through no fault of the respondent;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â That the facts alleged in the parking violation notice are
inconsistent or do not support a finding that the specified regulation was
violated. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-13: LESSOR OF VEHICLE; LIABILITY:
In accordance with section 11-1306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, no person who
is the lessor of a vehicle pursuant to a written lease agreement shall be
liable for a violation for any standing or parking regulation of this Code
involving such vehicle during the period of the lease if upon the receipt of a
notice of violation he shall, within sixty (60) days thereafter, provide to the
Code Administrator the name and address of the lessee. Upon receipt of a
lessor's notification of the name and address of his lessee, pursuant to
section 11-1305 or 11-1306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, the Code Administrator
shall cause a notice of violation to be sent to the lessee as provided herein.
If the lessor fails to provide the Code Administrator with the name and address
of the lessee within sixty (60) days of receiving notice, the lessor shall be
liable for the full amount of the violation and late penalties, and a final
determination will be issued. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-
2017)
1-8H-14: IMMOBILIZATION PROGRAM:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The Code Administrator is hereby authorized to direct and supervise a
Program of Vehicle Immobilization for the purpose of enforcing the parking
regulations of the Code. The Program of Vehicle Immobilization shall provide
for immobilizing of any eligible vehicle, as defined in subsection B of this
section, by placement of a restraint in such a manner as to prevent its
operation.
If the eligible vehicle is parked or left in violation of any provision of the
Traffic Code for which such vehicle is subject to an immediate tow, or in any
place where it constitutes an obstruction or hazard, or where it impedes City
workers during such operations as snow removal, the Code Administrator may
cause the eligible vehicle immediately to be towed to a vehicle pound or
relocated to a legal parking place and there restrained.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â When the registered owner of a vehicle has accumulated five (5) or more
final determinations of parking violation liability for which the fines and
penalties, if applicable, have not been paid in full, the Code Administrator
shall cause a notice of impending vehicle immobilization to be sent as
prescribed in this article.
The notice of impending vehicle immobilization shall state the name and address
of the registered owner, the state registration number of the vehicle or
vehicles registered to such owner, and the serial numbers of parking violation
notices which have resulted in final determination of liability for which the
fines or penalties remain unpaid. Failure to pay the fines and penalties owed
within thirty five (35) days from the date of the notice will result in the
inclusion of the state registration number of the vehicle of such owner on an
immobilization list. A person may challenge the validity of the notice of
impending vehicle immobilization by requesting a hearing and appearing in
person to submit evidence which would conclusively disprove eligibility. Such
hearing shall not be a forum to readjudicate the findings of fact and law
issued by the Hearing Officer. Upon a request for a hearing, the Code
Administrator shall schedule the hearing for the next regular hearing date.
Documentary evidence which would conclusively disprove liability shall be based
on the following grounds:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â That all fines and penalties for the parking violations cited in the
notice have been paid in full; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â That the registered owner has not accumulated five (5) or more final
determinations of parking violation liability which were unpaid at the time the
notice of impending vehicle immobilization was issued.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Upon immobilization of an eligible vehicle, a notice shall be affixed
to the vehicle in a conspicuous place. Such notice shall warn that the vehicle
is immobilized and that any attempt to move the vehicle may result in its
damage. The notice shall also state that the unauthorized removal or damage to
the immobilizing restraint is a violation of sections 16-1 and 21-1 of the
Illinois Criminal Code. The notice shall also provide information specifying
how release of the immobilizing restraint may be had, and how the registered
owner may obtain an immobilization hearing. If the restraint has not been
released within twenty four (24) hours of its placement, the restraint shall be
released and the vehicle towed and impounded.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The owner of an immobilized vehicle or other authorized person may
secure the release of the vehicle by paying the immobilization, towing and
storage fees provided in subsection G of this section, and all fines and
penalties remaining due on each final determination of parking violation
liability issued to such person.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The owner of an immobilized vehicle shall have the right to a hearing
to determine whether the immobilization or any subsequent towing and
impoundment was erroneous, if the owner files a written request for a hearing
with the Code Administrator within fourteen (14) days after immobilization or
fourteen (14) days of the date of the notice sent pursuant to subsection F of
this section, whichever is later. Such hearing shall not be a forum to
readjudicate the findings of fact and law issued by the Hearing Officer. The
determination of the Hearing Officer regarding the validity of the
immobilization shall become final for the purpose of judicial review under the
Administrative Review Law of Illinois upon issuance. The owner shall be limited
to the same defenses prescribed in subsection B of this section.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Within ten (10) days after a vehicle has been impounded, a notice of
impoundment shall be sent by first class mail, to the address of the registered
owner as listed with the Secretary of State. The notice shall state that the
owner has the right to request a postimmobilization and posttowing hearing as
provided in subsection E of this section, and that if the vehicle is not
claimed within sixty (60) days from the date of the notice, the vehicle may be
sold or otherwise disposed of in accordance with section 4-208 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â The fee for immobilization shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). In
addition, a fee for towing subsequent to the immobilization and a storage fee
for every twenty four (24) hour period the vehicle is retained shall be
assessed. No fees shall be assessed for any immobilization or tow which has
been determined to be erroneous.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful to relocate any vehicle restrained by an
immobilization device without the approval of the Code Administrator or his
designee. The registered owner of the immobilized vehicle and any person who
relocates an immobilized vehicle in violation of this subsection shall each be
subject to a penalty of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such
violation. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-15: DRIVER'S LICENSE SUSPENSION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â When a person has failed to pay any fine or penalty due and owing
pursuant to this article on ten (10) or more parking violations, the Code
Administrator shall cause a notice of impending driver's license suspension to
be sent in the form as required by the Secretary of State. The notice shall
state that failure to pay the amount owing within forty five (45) days of the
date of the notice will result in the City notifying the Secretary of State
that the person is eligible for initiation of suspension proceedings pursuant
to section 6-306.5 of the Illinois Vehicle Code.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If a person sent a notice pursuant to subsection A of this section
fails to pay the amount owing within the time stated on the notice, the Code
Administrator may file with the Secretary of State, a certified report, in
accordance with section 6-306.5(c) of the Illinois Vehicle Code, that the
person is eligible for initiation of suspension proceedings. The Code
Administrator shall assess a twenty dollar ($20.00) filing fee against the
person named in the certified report to reimburse the City for the expense of
preparing and filing the certified report with the Secretary of State.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â A person named in a certified report filed pursuant to subsection B of
this section may, within twenty one (21) days of the date of the notice sent by
the Secretary of State pursuant to section 6-306.5(b) of the Illinois Vehicle
Code, file with the Code Administrator a written statement and supporting
documentation to challenge the report; provided, however, the grounds for such
challenge shall be limited to: 1) the person not having been the owner or
lessee of the vehicle or vehicles receiving ten (10) or more parking violation
notices on the date or dates such notices were issued; 2) the person having
already paid the fine and penalty for the ten (10) or more violations indicated
on the report; or 3) the person not having accumulated ten (10) or more final
determinations of parking violation liability. The Code Administrator shall
send notice of the decision on the challenge to the report after the receipt
thereof.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â If a person named in a certified report has paid the previously
reported fine or penalty or if the report is determined by the Code
Administrator to be in error, the Code Administrator shall notify the Secretary
of State in accordance with section 6-306.5(d) of the Illinois Vehicle Code. A
certified copy of such notification shall be given, upon request and at no
charge, to the person named therein.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â An administrative hearing to contest an impending suspension or
suspension may be had upon filing a written request with the Secretary of
State. Such hearing shall not be a forum to readjudicate the findings of fact
and law issued by the Hearing Officer. The filing fee for this hearing shall be
twenty dollars ($20.00) to be paid at the time the request is made. The City
shall reimburse the Secretary of State for all reasonable costs incurred by the
Secretary as a result of filing a certified report, including, but not limited
to, the costs of providing the required notice and the costs incurred by the
Secretary at any hearing conducted with respect to the report and any appeal
from such a hearing. In the event the owner is found eligible for suspension,
such owner shall reimburse the City for all of the foregoing costs. (Ord. 16-O-
23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-16: BUILDING CODE VIOLATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Building Code Violation Reports: When a Code Enforcement Officer or his
designee finds a Building Code violation while inspecting a structure, he shall
note the violation on a multiple copy violation notice and report form,
indicating:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The name and address of the structure owner;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A citation to the specific Building Code provision or provisions
alleged to have been violated, including the maximum penalty;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A description of the circumstances present that constitute the
alleged violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The date and time the violation was observed;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The names of witnesses to the violation; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The address of the structure where the violation is observed.
The violation report form shall be forwarded by the Code Enforcement Officer,
or his designee, to the Code Hearing Department where a docket number shall be
stamped on all copies of the report, and a hearing date noted in the blank
spaces provided for that purpose on the form. The hearing date shall not be
less than thirty (30) nor more than forty (40) days after the violation is
reported by the building inspector.
One (1) copy of the violation report form shall be maintained in the files of
the Code Hearing Department and shall be part of the record of hearing, one (1)
copy of the report form shall be returned to the Code Enforcement Officer so
that he may prepare evidence of the Code violation for presentation at the
hearing on the date indicated, and one (1) copy of the report form shall be
served by first class mail on the owner of the structure, along with a summons
commanding the owner to appear at the hearing. If the name of the owner of the
structure cannot be ascertained or if service on the owner cannot be made by
mail, service may be made on the owner by posting or nailing a copy of the
violation report form on the front door of the structure where the violation is
found, not less than twenty (20) days before the hearing is scheduled.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Defenses To Building Code Violations: It shall be a defense to a
Building Code violation charged if the owner, his attorney, or any other agent
or representative proves to the Hearing Officer's satisfaction that:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The Building Code violation alleged in the notice does not in fact
exist, or at the time of the hearing, the violation has been remedied or
removed;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The Building Code violation has been caused by the current property
occupants and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the owner to maintain the
dwelling free of such violations, the current occupants continue to cause the
violations;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â An occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to the
owner or his agent to all or part of the dwelling for the purpose of correcting
the Building Code violation.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Sanctions Applicable To Owner; Property: The order to correct a
Building Code violation and the sanction imposed by the City as the result of a
finding of a Building Code violation under this article shall attach to the
property as well as to the owner of the property, so that a finding of a
Building Code violation against one (1) owner cannot be avoided by conveying or
transferring the property to another owner. Any subsequent transferee or owner
of property takes subject to the findings, decision and order of a Hearing
Officer under this article.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Any transfers or conveyances of properties subject to an order to
correct a Code violation shall be reported by the respondent to the Code
Administrator or their designee within one (1) business day of the transfer or
conveyance. Failure to do so shall constitute a violation of this Code and be
subject to a minimum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for every day the violation of
failing to report occurs.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A mortgagee in possession of a property, the beneficial owners of
real property held in trust, and any person, business, partnership, corporation
or other entity who contracts with the Federal government or any of its
agencies, including, without limitation, the Department of Housing and Urban
Development, to care for vacant residential real estate shall be responsible
for maintaining the property to prevent and correct City of Charleston Health
and Safety Code violations.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Hearing: At the hearing, a Hearing Officer shall preside and shall hear
testimony and accept any evidence relevant to the existence or nonexistence of
a Code violation in the structure indicated. The strict rules of evidence
applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply. At the conclusion of the
hearing, the Hearing Officer shall make a determination on the basis of the
evidence presented at the hearing whether or not a Building Code violation
exists. The determination shall be in writing and shall be designated as a
"findings, decision and order". The findings, decision and order shall include
the Hearing Officer's findings of fact, a decision whether or not a Code
violation exists based upon the findings of fact, and an order, ordering the
owner to correct the violation or dismissing the case, in the event a violation
is not proved. If a Code violation is proved, the order may also impose the
sanctions that are provided in the Building Code for the violation proved. A
copy of the findings, decision, and order shall be served on the owner within
five (5) days after they are issued; service shall be in the same manner as the
report form and summons are served pursuant to subsection A of this section.
(Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-17: PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person found liable of a violation of any section of this article
shall be fined in a sum not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). A
separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day such duty or
obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise
specifically provided for in this Code.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If a Code violation is proved and the respondent is ordered to pay the
costs of the administrative adjudication proceeding, the costs shall be ordered
to be paid by the respondent, including, but not limited to, costs for Hearing
Officer, file management, document automation and recordkeeping, recording
costs, costs of peer courts or panels, hearing security, prosecutor fees and
other related costs. The costs shall become an amount due and owing to the City
and shall be part of the order issued against the violator.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â A respondent who fails to pay the original fine and costs after thirty
five (35) days of the issuance of the final determination of liability shall be
liable, if found guilty, for both the original fine and a late payment penalty.
The late payment penalty is cumulative and in addition to the original fine.
The late payment penalty will be stayed if a respondent files for
administrative review within thirty five (35) days after the entry of a final
determination of liability. The penalty for late payment shall be as set forth
on the following schedule:
LATE PAYMENT SCHEDULE
Â 
Original Fine         Late Payment Penalty
Â Â Â $25.00 - $49.00 $50.00 - cumulative
Â Â Â $50.00 - $99.00 $100.00
Â Â Â $100.00 or great$200.00
Â 
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The fine, penalties, and costs may be assigned to a collection agency
ninety (90) days after the issuance of the final determination of liability.
Fines and fees referred to a collection agency will automatically subject the
respondent to an additional administrative fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00),
to offset the cost of assigning the fine to a collection agency for processing
on the City's behalf. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-18: SETTLEMENT OF VIOLATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A person accused of violating a section of this City Code prosecuted
through administrative adjudication may offer to settle the case by an amount
set forth in the sworn pleading, violation notice, complaint or citation,
within the time and in the manner set forth in subsection B of this section.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Payments in settlement of violations set forth in this City Code shall
be made on or before five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on the last business day, prior
to the hearing date. A payment shall be considered made if the payment is
actually received by the City's Comptroller's Office, or such other place as
designated for receipt of fines, on or before five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on the
last business day, prior to the hearing date. Payments shall be made by cash or
certified check, money order, or cashier's check made payable to the City of
Charleston, or such other forms of tender as the Comptroller's Office shall
specify.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The City Attorney or his or her designee may, at his or her discretion,
elect to reject any such fine as settlement of any violations set forth prior
to the date the written sworn pleading, violation notice, complaint or citation
which charges a person with such violation is filed with the Code
Administrator. In addition, if a violation proximately causes actual out of
pocket expenses for loss to the victim or victims of said violation, the City
Attorney or his or her designee may elect to accept payment of restitution to
the victim or victims of the said violation in addition to payment of the fine
set forth, as settlement of a violation prior to and in lieu of filing a
complaint for the same.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Peace officers who have issued a City Code violation and notice of
hearing with the Code Hearing Department to a person for an offense under this
Code shall deliver the original copies of the City Code violation and notice of
hearing to the Code Administrator.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â If a respondent pays a fine pursuant to this section, and such payment
is not rejected under subsection C of this section, then the complaint charging
the respondent with the particular violation shall not be filed by the City in
either the Circuit Court or with the Administrative Code Department, or if
filed, shall be dismissed with no administrative costs assessed.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Respondents issued a City Code violation and notice of hearing with the
Administrative Code Department for these offenses must appear at the
administrative adjudicatory hearing, unless otherwise notified by the Code
Hearing Department. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-2017)
1-8H-19: SEVERABILITY:
It is declared to be the intention of the City Council that the sections,
subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, and words of this Code and article
are severable. If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or word
is declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by the lawful judgment or
decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, its unconstitutionality or
invalidity shall not affect the validity of any of the remaining sections,
subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and words of this Code and article,
since the sections or parts of sections would have been enacted by the City
Council without and irrespective of any unconstitutional or otherwise invalid
section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or word being incorporated
into this Code and article. (Ord. 16-O-23, 6-7-2016; amd. Ord. 17-O-26, 7-5-
2017)

ARTICLE J. DEPARTMENT OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY
SECTION:
1-8J-1:Â Â Â  Department Created
1-8J-2:Â Â Â  Joint Information Technology Director
1-8J-3:Â Â Â  Information Services Director
1-8J-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created the Department of Information Technology, an executive
office of the city, and the position of joint information technology director,
information services director and information services support specialist.
(Ord. 2025-O-5, 2-18-2025)
1-8J-2: JOINT INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY DIRECTOR:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Appointment; Term; Compensation: The joint information technology (IT)
director shall be appointed by the city manager and shall serve at the pleasure
of the city manager. For such services rendered, the joint information
technology director shall be paid a salary provided by the city council.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The purpose of this position is to perform all functions related to
support the work of the City of Charleston and Coles County employees. The
joint IT director reports to the city manager and serves at the pleasure of the
city manager. The joint IT director is a position that has job duties and
responsibilities that overlap between the City of Charleston and Coles County.
Work on behalf of the City of Charleston is performed under the general
direction of the city manager.
Through the merging of resources to purchase key infrastructure pieces, the
City of Charleston and Coles County are joined together such that what affects
one agency invariably affects the other. To help maintain stability in this
infrastructure, a Joint IT Director position has been created. This position
will oversee the management of all shared information technology resources that
have been purchased by or directly benefit both agencies. The objects managed
include hardware and software currently in service as well as future expansion
and technology growth. (Ord. 2025-O-5, 2-18-2025)
1-8J-3: INFORMATION SERVICES DIRECTOR:
The information services director shall be appointed by the city manager and
serve at the pleasure of the city manager. The information services director
shall report to the city manager, or their designee, and assist the deputy city
manager(s). (Ord. 2025-O-5, 2-18-2025)
