3-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires, the terms
specified in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this
section.
ADVANCED LIFE SUPPORT/MOBILE INTENSIVE CARE (ALS/MIC): An advanced level of
prehospital and interhospital care that includes basic life support functions
(including cardiopulmonary resuscitation [CPR] plus cardiac monitoring, cardiac
defibrillation, telemetered electrocardiography, administration of
antiarrhythmic agents, intravenous therapy, administration of medications,
drugs and solutions, use of adjunctive medical devices, trauma care, and other
authorized techniques and procedures) initiated for the treatment of real or
potential acute life threatening conditions under the direction of a physician
licensed to practice medicine in all of its branches or a registered
professional nurse/MICN or registered professional nurse/field RN, and where
authorized by a project medical director in an Illinois department of public
health approved advanced life support system.
AMBULANCE: Any publicly or privately owned vehicle that is specifically
designed, constructed or modified and equipped, and is intended to be used for,
and is maintained or operated for the emergency transportation of persons who
are sick, injured, wounded or otherwise incapacitated or helpless.
AMBULANCE SERVICE: The operation of an enterprise which has as one of its
purposes the operation, or use on the streets, alleys, or any public way within
the city of an ambulance which responds to emergency calls for the
transportation of persons who are reported to be sick, injured, wounded,
otherwise incapacitated or helpless.
AMBULANCE SERVICE LOCATION: The location at which ambulances are stored,
maintained or from which ambulances are dispatched by an ambulance service.
BASIC LIFE SUPPORT SERVICES (BLS): The rendering of basic level of prehospital
and interhospital emergency care, including, but not limited to, airway
management, cardiopulmonary resuscitation, control of shock and bleeding and
splinting of fractures, as outlined in a basic emergency care course approved
by the Illinois department of public health and meeting the current national
curriculum requirements of the United States department of transportation.
CHANGE IN AMBULANCE: A change by either adding or removing from service an
ambulance from the list of those previously approved by the fire chief.
CHANGE IN AMBULANCE SERVICE LOCATION: A change by either adding or removing
from use as part of the ambulance service a storage, dispatch or maintenance
facility used in the ambulance service from the list of those previously
approved by the fire chief.
EMERGENCY: A condition or situation in which an individual declares a need for
immediate attention or when that need is declared by emergency medical
personnel or a public safety official.
EMERGENCY CALL: The request by radio, telephone, telecommunications device for
the deaf (TDD), or in person for ambulance service to respond to an emergency.
EMERGENCY MEDICAL TECHNICIAN-BASIC (EMT-B): A person who has successfully
completed a course of instruction in basic life support services as required by
and is currently certified by the Illinois department of public health in
accordance with standards prescribed by the emergency medical services (EMS)
systems act for the state of Illinois or by rules adopted pursuant to said act,
who provides emergency medical services.
EMERGENCY MEDICAL TECHNICIAN-INTERMEDIATE (EMT-I): An EMT-I currently certified
by the department who has completed a department approved course of instruction
in specific advanced life support/mobile intensive care services and who is
currently functioning in a program approved by the Illinois department of
public health to provide such services under the supervision and control of a
project medical director.
EMERGENCY MEDICAL TECHNICIAN-PARAMEDIC (EMT-P): A person who has successfully
completed an Illinois department of public health approved course of
instruction in advanced life support/mobile intensive care services and is
currently certified by the Illinois department of public health.
EMERGENCY RESPONSE BUSINESS RECORDS: Those records which document the staff on
duty for the ambulance service at any time and records which establish the
staff's minimum qualifications required by this chapter, documents which record
the number of responses to emergency calls, response times to emergency calls,
maintenance of records of the ambulance, phone logs indicating emergency calls
for service and such other documents, tape recordings, computer records or
other media which contain information necessary or convenient for the fire
chief to determine if the ambulance service has or is complying with the
provisions of this title and the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to
this chapter.
FIRE DEPARTMENT: The fire department of the city of Charleston.
HOSPITAL: The meaning ascribed to that term in the state of Illinois hospital
licensing act, as that act is now or may hereafter be amended.
ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH: The department of public health, state of
Illinois, or its successor in function.
INTERMEDIATE LIFE SUPPORT CARE: Intermediate level of prehospital and
interhospital emergency care that includes BLS care, plus intravenous
cannulation and fluid therapy, invasive airway management, trauma care, and
other authorized techniques and procedures initiated for the treatment of real
or potential acute life threatening conditions, under the direction of a
physician licensed to practice medicine in all its branches or a registered
professional nurse/MICN or registered professional nurse/field RN, and where
authorized by a project medical director in a department approved EMS system.
MUTUAL AID AGREEMENT: An intergovernmental or interagency agreement providing
for shared and common assistance when requested by one of the member agencies.
The equipment and personnel provided by a mutual aid request may be
predetermined for a particular type of incident or determined at the time of
the request in consideration of available resources.
POLICE DEPARTMENT: The police department of the city of Charleston.
REGISTERED PROFESSIONAL NURSE/FIELD RN: A registered nurse, licensed under the
"Illinois nursing act", who has been approved by the project medical director
in an Illinois department of public health approved EMS system, and who has
satisfactorily completed additional supplementary training, including, but not
limited to, courses in extrication; telemetry and communications; advanced
cardiac life support, including defibrillation and intubation or its equivalent
and either trauma nurse specialist or nurse trauma life support or their
equivalents as approved by the project medical director.
REGISTERED PROFESSIONAL NURSE/MICN: A registered nurse, licensed under the
"Illinois nursing act", as amended, who has satisfactorily completed the mobile
intensive care nurse course, including training in telemetry and
communications, advanced cardiac life support, and a prehospital trauma support
course or its equivalent, as approved by the Illinois department of public
health.
SERVICE ZONE: A geographical area defined by boundaries mutually agreed to by
the fire chief and ambulance service and illustrated by the map attached to the
emergency medical services rules and regulations.
TRANSFER: The nonemergency transfer of a patient from one medical facility to
another. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-2: AMBULANCE SERVICE LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Ambulance Service License Required: No person, whether acting as owner,
principal, agent, employee, lessee or licensee, shall furnish, operate,
conduct, advertise, or otherwise engage in ambulance service in the city of
Charleston without a current ambulance service license issued pursuant to this
chapter by the city of Charleston or in violation of the terms or conditions of
the license.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Ambulance Service License Not Required: No ambulance license is
required by:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â An ambulance service which has no maintenance, dispatch or storage
facilities in the city of Charleston and which does not respond to an emergency
with the city of Charleston; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â An ambulance service authorized by the fire chief to operate without
a license in accordance with section
3-10-20 of this chapter. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-3: APPLICATION PROCEDURE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The application for license as an ambulance service shall be filed with
the city clerk on a form prescribed and furnished by the city of Charleston.
The application shall include, but not be limited to, the following
information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Applicant's name, address, and trade or other assumed name under
which the applicant proposes to operate the ambulance service.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Name and address of each owner of the ambulance service.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Description of each ambulance to be used in the operations during
the period of the license.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Address and location from which an ambulance or ambulances will be
operated, stored, dispatched or maintained by the ambulance service whether
located in or outside the city of Charleston.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â List of personnel of the ambulance service with EMT certification
and the personnel's respective EMT certifications.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â At the time the application for license is submitted, the license fee
shall also be submitted. The cost of the licensing fee shall be one hundred
twenty five dollars ($125.00) per year. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-4: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Upon receipt of an application for an ambulance service license, the
fire chief shall cause an investigation of the applicant and the proposed
operations. Such investigation shall be completed within fifteen (15) business
days from receipt of the application and license fee unless the ambulance
service agrees to an extension of time.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The fire chief shall approve the issuance of an ambulance service
license to the applicant unless the fire chief, after reasonable investigation,
finds that the applicant or the staff proposed to be used by the applicant, or
a vehicle or vehicles proposed to be used by the applicant do not meet the
requirements of this chapter, or the provisions of this code relating to the
denial of a license, or other requirements imposed by law.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Each license shall be issued to the person named in the application for
the ambulances and locations specified in the application. The license may not
be transferred or assigned to any other person.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â A copy of each license issued by the fire chief shall be filed with the
city clerk. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-5: EXPIRATION OF AMBULANCE SERVICE LICENSE:
Each license shall expire on April 30 following date of its issuance. (Ord. 08-
O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-6: RENEWAL APPLICATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The annual license renewal fee and an application for renewal of an
ambulance service license shall be filed with the city clerk on a form
prescribed and furnished by the city of Charleston no sooner than ninety (90)
days prior to the license expiration but no later than sixty (60) days prior to
the license expiration. Failure to submit a license renewal application within
the prescribed time period shall be grounds for denying the renewal license.
The ambulance service denied a renewal license for this reason may apply for a
new license at any time.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â An application for renewal of an ambulance service license may be
denied for the same reasons that an original application for an ambulance
service license may be denied. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-7: AMBULANCE AVAILABILITY, DESIGN, AND EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â An ambulance service licensed to operate within the city limits of the
city of Charleston shall maintain at least two (2) ALS units in the city limits
at all times for responses.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â An ambulance service licensed to operate within the city limits of the
city of Charleston shall provide coverage in "zones" mutually agreed to by the
applicant ambulance service and the fire chief. Coverage will be defined in the
"EMS Response And Deployment Rules And Regulations".
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â An ambulance service licensed to operate within the city limits of the
city of Charleston shall be capable of responding two (2) units in most
circumstances for additional help.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â An ambulance service licensed to operate within the city limits of the
city of Charleston must enter into a mutual assistance agreement relating to
ambulance service pursuant to the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-5-7. Said agreement shall not prohibit the city of Charleston nor shall it
prohibit the ambulance service from entering into other mutual ambulance
assistance agreements with other ambulance services.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â An ambulance service licensed to operate within the city limits of the
city of Charleston must execute an agreement for participation in the mutual
aid box alarm system (MABAS), a copy of said agreement being supplied to the
fire chief.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â In addition to the coverage provided in the zones referenced above,
each ambulance service shall be required, at the direction of the fire chief,
to respond with available ambulances to locations outside of the Charleston
city limits as part of a response to a request from the state of Illinois or
another local governmental unit pursuant to any mutual aid agreement the city
has with the state of Illinois or another unit of local government. Said
ambulance service shall not be entitled to reimbursement for the costs of its
response to said mutual aid request unless, and only, to the extent that the
city of Charleston receives payments or reimbursement for said services.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Each ambulance used or proposed to be used in a licensed ambulance
service shall meet the same design and equipment requirements that the
ambulance would be required to meet in order to be licensed by the state of
Illinois now or as may be required hereafter by the state of Illinois by
amendment.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Additional ambulance requirements for operating within the Charleston
city limits include the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â All ambulances licensed to operate within the city of Charleston
shall be type III ALS ambulances; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â All ambulances licensed to operate within the city of Charleston
shall be equipped with Zoll biphasic monitors; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â All ambulances licensed to operate within the city of Charleston
shall be equipped with radios that have all MABAS channels in the units and
IFERN1, IFERN2, and interoperable communications with other state and local
agencies; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â All ambulances licensed to operate within the city of Charleston
shall be IO drill equipped; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â All ambulances licensed to operate within the city of Charleston
shall have the capability of taking critical care EMT-P calls; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â All ambulances licensed to operate within the city of Charleston
shall have the capability of providing extrication and/or specialized rescues
(high angle vertical, confined space, trench and structural collapse).
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â An ambulance shall be considered available for use by the ambulance
service if it is under the sole control of the ambulance service for its sole
use and it is operational, stored and dispatched by the ambulance service from
within the Charleston city limits or a location approved by the fire chief.
(Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-8: EMT REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â When in use for emergency calls, each ambulance shall have as personnel
in the ambulance two (2) EMT-Ps on all calls.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Each licensed ambulance service must maintain at least two (2) units in
town at all times with two (2) EMT-Ps at minimum.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â A registered professional nurse/MICN, registered professional nurse/
field RN, or physician may be counted as an EMT-P for purposes of meeting the
requirements of this section.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Additional training requirements for operating within the Charleston
city limits shall include the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â All personnel are trained in technical rescue awareness.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â All personnel are trained in emergency response to terrorism basic
concepts.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â All personnel shall be trained annually on the Charleston fire
department's incident command system.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â All personnel are certified FSVO (fire service vehicle operator).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â All personnel are NIMS compliant with certificates in IS 100; IS
200; and IS 700.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â All supervisors have supervisory training equal to two hundred (200)
hours.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â All supervisors are NIMS compliant with IS 300; IS 400 and unified
command.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Each ambulance unit operating must be staffed by a minimum of one
EMT-P trained in hazardous material operations for emergency medical services
by their employer.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Each ambulance service shall provide a copy of documentation to the
fire chief or fire chief's designee showing annual certification of required
training. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-9: CHANGE IN LOCATION OF AMBULANCE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A licensed ambulance service shall notify the fire chief in writing at
least one hundred twenty (120) business days prior to changing the location of
its operations. For purposes of this section, "location of operations" means
the zone where ambulances and staff are located while on duty awaiting to be
dispatched.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The fire chief shall approve or deny the request within ten (10)
business days after receipt of a request. The fire chief shall notify the city
clerk of any approved change of location. The fire chief shall approve the
change in location unless the proposed change would violate this code or any
provision of an ordinance of the city or state or federal law or regulations.
(Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-10: APPROVAL AND NOTIFICATION OF USE AND DECOMMISSIONING OF AMBULANCE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No person, either as owner, agent or otherwise, shall operate or allow
another person to operate an ambulance to respond to an emergency call for or
on behalf of a licensed ambulance service unless its use for such purpose is
approved by the fire chief.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All requests for approval to use an ambulance under this section shall
be submitted in writing to the fire chief on a form provided by the fire chief.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The fire chief shall approve the use of an ambulance within fifteen
(15) business days of receipt of the written request unless its use would
violate a provision of this code, any rules or regulations promulgated to
implement this chapter, an ordinance of the city, or a state or federal law or
regulation.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â A licensed ambulance service shall notify the fire chief in writing
within five (5) business days after it permanently ceases use of an ambulance.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The fire chief shall notify the city clerk of the change in licensing.
(Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-11: CHANGE IN OWNERSHIP:
A licensed ambulance service shall report in writing to the fire chief any
change in ownership sixty (60) calendar days prior to change in ownership. The
fire chief may deny issuance of license if the owners do not meet this code,
provisions of an ordinance of the city, state, federal law or regulation. The
fire chief shall notify the city clerk of any change in ownership. For purposes
of this section, "change in ownership" shall mean the transfer of all or any
part of an interest in a sole proprietorship or partnership or the transfer of
more than five percent (5%) of the stock of a private corporation or twenty
five percent (25%) of the stock of a public corporation. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-
2008)
3-10-12: PROVISION OF AMBULANCE SERVICE REGARDLESS OF ABILITY TO PAY OR
LOCATION OF SERVICES:
Each licensed ambulance service shall provide emergency service within the city
of Charleston without regard to a person's ability to pay for such service or
the location of requested services. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-13: USE OF UNAPPROVED AMBULANCE OR LOCATION PROHIBITED:
No person, either as owner, agent or otherwise, shall operate or maintain an
ambulance service at a location not approved by the fire chief. (Ord. 08-O-14,
5-20-2008)
3-10-14: COMPLIANCE WITH EMERGENCY DISPATCH PROCEDURES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Each licensed ambulance service shall comply with all emergency
dispatch procedures established by the city of Charleston fire department and
police department and any dispatching agency for the fire or police department.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If for any reason a licensed ambulance service is not able to comply
with the operational requirements set forth in this section, it shall
immediately report that status to the Charleston fire department in accordance
with the fire chief's emergency dispatch procedures.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â An ambulance service shall not respond to any requests for emergency
assistance unless it is in compliance with the operation requirements set forth
in this chapter, unless specifically authorized to respond by the fire chief or
the fire chief's designee as provided for the fire chief's emergency dispatch
procedures.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â An ambulance service licensed to operate within the Charleston city
limits shall have in place and utilize the current system used for emergency
medical dispatch (EMD). (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-15: MONITORING EMERGENCY DISPATCH CALLS:
It shall be unlawful for any ambulance service to respond in or through the
city to a call for an ambulance made by an organized police or fire department
or any such department's official dispatching agency unless a specific request
is directed to the ambulance service by the organized police or fire department
or any such department's official dispatching agency. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-16: IMMEDIATE EMERGENCY RESPONSE REQUIRED:
Each licensed ambulance service shall immediately respond to any emergency call
for an ambulance directed to that ambulance service and originated by the
Charleston fire or police department or any such department's official
dispatching agency. If the licensed ambulance service is not able to
immediately respond to the emergency or is not able to respond with an
appropriate or requested level of service, the licensed ambulance service shall
immediately report this situation to the agency and shall follow the directions
of that agency regarding the response. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-17: RESPONSE TIMES:
Any ambulance service licensed to operate within the Charleston city limits
shall meet the following response criteria:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â "Response time" is defined as the amount of time that has elapsed
between the time when the call is received by the ambulance service until the
time of arrival at the scene of the emergency.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The ALS ambulance should arrive at the scene of the emergency within
eight (8) minutes of the time the call was received by the ambulance service.
This time criteria must be met on at least ninety percent (90%) of the calls
received during any period of six (6) consecutive months. This applies to all
ALS units on code response (lights and sirens).
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â All other noncode responses should arrive on scene within twelve (12)
minutes of the time the call was received by the ambulance service. This time
criteria must be met on at least ninety percent (90%) of the calls received
during any period of six (6) consecutive months.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Any ambulance service licensed to operate within the Charleston city
limits shall provide to the fire chief or fire chief's designee a written
biannual report on or before April 30 and on or before October 31 showing
response time compliance. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-18: AUTHORITY TO PROMULGATE AMBULANCE OPERATION EMERGENCY DISPATCH
PROCEDURES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The fire chief is hereby granted the authority to promulgate rules and
regulations for governing the emergency dispatch of ambulances in order to
promote the safe response of ambulances in an emergency.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any emergency dispatch rules and regulations promulgated by the fire
chief shall not conflict with the provisions of this code and shall be
considered supplemental to this code.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The emergency dispatch rules and regulations shall provide for the
selection of a licensed ambulance service to be dispatched in an emergency
requiring the response of an ambulance. The rules and regulations may provide
that the selection of an ambulance in any situation may be based on rotational,
geographical or other criteria as the fire chief shall determine will promote
an orderly response by persons with sufficient training and experience to
respond to the emergency.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The fire chief shall file any rule or regulation promulgated pursuant
to this section with the city clerk and shall mail a copy of any such rule or
regulation to each licensed ambulance service, to the police chief, and to all
official dispatching agencies for the Charleston fire or police department
pursuant to this code at the time the rule or regulation is promulgated and at
least seven (7) calendar days prior to such rule or regulation taking effect.
(Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-19: RIGHT TO INSPECT OPERATIONAL LOCATIONS AND AMBULANCES:
The fire chief shall have the right to inspect all operational locations and
ambulances proposed to be used or used by a licensed ambulance service at any
reasonable time and investigate the emergency response business records of the
applicant and staff to be used in the ambulance service at reasonable times,
provided, however, that the fire chief shall not be allowed to inspect those
portions of records which are prohibited from inspection by federal or state
law. Should the ambulance service refuse to allow inspection of a portion of a
record due to a federal or state law, the fire chief may require that the
ambulance service specify the particular law which restricts inspection and
shall be allowed to inspect those portions of the records that are not
prohibited by law from disclosure. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
3-10-20: RIGHT OF FIRE CHIEF TO AUTHORIZE SERVICE BY UNLICENSED VEHICLES:
In the case of an emergency where the number of licensed ambulances available
is determined by the fire chief to be insufficient to render the required
emergency ambulance service, the fire chief may authorize nonlicensed vehicles
to operate as ambulances in response to the emergency. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-
2008)
3-10-21: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The fire chief may impose fines against or suspend or revoke the license of a
licensed ambulance service for any violations of the provisions of this chapter
or any rules or regulations promulgated to implement the provisions of this
chapter, in accordance with the provisions of this title or any amendment
thereto. (Ord. 08-O-14, 5-20-2008)
CHAPTER 11
TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND ITINERANT VENDORS
SECTION:
3-11-1: Definitions
3-11-2: License Required
3-11-3: Application
3-11-4: Conditions
3-11-5: Denial Or Revocation Of License
3-11-6: Penalties
3-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this chapter:
ITINERANT VENDOR: Any person who transports tangible personal property for
retail sale within this State who does not maintain in this State an
established office, distribution house, sales house, warehouse, service center
or residence from which such business is conducted. However, this chapter does
not apply to any person who delivers tangible personal property within this
State who is fulfilling an order for such property which was solicited or
placed by mail or other means.
PERSON: Any individual, corporation, partnership, trust, firm, association or
other entity.
TRANSIENT MERCHANT: Any person who is engaged temporarily in the retail sale of
goods, wares or merchandise in this State and who, for the purpose of
conducting such business, occupies any building, room, vehicle, structure of
any kind, or vacant lot. However, this chapter does not apply to any person
selling goods, wares or merchandise which are raised, produced or manufactured
by him, to any person selling vegetables, fruit or perishable farm products at
an established City market, to any person operating a store or refreshment
stand at a resort, to any person operating a stand or booth on or adjacent to
property owned by him or upon which he resides, to any person operating a stand
or booth at a State or County Fair, or to any person operating a stand or booth
at a trade show, exposition, convention or similar event. (Ord. 17-O-11, 4-18-
2017)
3-11-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is a violation of this chapter for any person, either as principal or agent,
to conduct business as a transient merchant or itinerant vendor in the City
without first complying with the requirements of section 2a of the Retailers'
Occupation Tax Act 1  by obtaining a certificate of registration and, if a bond
or other security is required, by posting bond or other approved security, and
without having obtained a license under this chapter. (Ord. 17-O-11, 4-18-2017)

Notes
1 1. 35 ILCS 120/2a.
3-11-3: APPLICATION:
Any person who wishes to obtain a license as a transient merchant or itinerant
vendor shall file a written license application with the Police Department as
provided in this section.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The license application shall include the applicant's:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Name;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Permanent business address (which must include a street address);
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Residence address of the principal (and, if the applicant is a
corporation, the residence addresses of its officers);
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The location at which the applicant intends to do business, and
proof of the property owner's permission to do business at that location;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The nature of the business the applicant intends to conduct;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â A copy of the applicant's certificate of registration under the
Retailers' Occupation Tax Act;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â A complete inventory of the goods the applicant intends to offer for
sale; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â A list of all licenses to conduct business as a transient merchant
or an itinerant vendor obtained by the applicant in this State in the twelve
(12) months preceding the date of filing of the application, and disclosure of
any revocation of such licenses.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A license issued under this chapter shall expire on December 31 of the
year it was issued. The Police Department may collect a license application fee
of one hundred dollars ($100.00) from any person wishing to conduct business as
either a transient merchant or itinerant vendor under this chapter. (Ord. 17-O-
21, 5-16-2017)
3-11-4: CONDITIONS:
Any license issued under this chapter is expressly conditioned on compliance
with all applicable laws, including the Transient Merchant Act of 1987, 225
Illinois Compiled Statutes 465/1 et seq. (Ord. 17-O-11, 4-18-2017)
3-11-5: DENIAL OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The Police Department will send the applicant or licensee a "notice of
denial" or "notice of revocation" for a license under this chapter by first
class mail, if the Police Department determines that the applicant or licensee:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Made any material misrepresentation or false statement in the
license application;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Failed to comply with applicable laws, including registration with
the Illinois Department of Revenue for the payment of Sales Tax;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Failed to conduct and/or supervise activities under the license so
as to reasonably ensure that such activities are in compliance with the terms
of the license and with the provisions of this chapter; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Authorized, condoned, or knowingly tolerated any unlawful activities
or any activities conducted under the license in such a manner as to constitute
a nuisance, crime, fraud, trespass, or invasion of privacy.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Within five (5) business days of the "notice of denial" or "notice of
revocation", the applicant or licensee may submit a written request to the
Mayor for a hearing to dispute the license denial or revocation.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Within five (5) business days of the applicant or licensee's request
for a hearing, the Mayor will submit a "notice of hearing" to the applicant or
licensee by first class mail, not less than five (5) business days prior to the
date of the hearing. The "notice of hearing" will describe the Police
Department's grounds for denial or revocation of the license, and notify the
applicant of the time and place of the hearing, and their right to counsel, to
submit evidence, and to cross examine witnesses.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The Mayor will deny the application or revoke the license:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â In the absence of a timely request for hearing; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Upon finding of grounds for denial or revocation of the license
based upon the preponderance of the evidence after a hearing. (Ord. 17-O-11, 4-
18-2017)
3-11-6: PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â If any person makes retail sales as a transient merchant or itinerant
vendor without having obtained a license under this chapter, the Police
Department may hold the inventory, truck, or other personal property of the
person until he obtains a license to conduct business as a transient merchant
or itinerant vendor.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the property has been held by the Police Department for more than
sixty (60) days and the person whose property is being held has not obtained a
license under this chapter, the Police Department, or the City, may petition
the Circuit Court for an order for the sale of the property being held.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â If the court finds that the person whose property is held has not
obtained a license under this chapter, the court may order the Police
Department or City to sell the property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Proceeds of the sale of the property, less reimbursement to the
Police Department of the reasonable expenses of storage and sale of the
property, shall be deposited in the Treasury of the City.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Notwithstanding any other remedies available to the City pursuant to
this chapter, any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall
be punished by a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)
for each offense, to which court or adjudication costs may be added. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day on which the violation occurs or
continues to occur. (Ord. 17-O-11, 4-18-2017)

FIREWORKS
SECTION:

3-12-1: STORING OR SELLING FIREWORKS PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person to store, sell, offer or expose for
sale, or have in possession with intent to sell or to use, discharge or cause
to be discharged, ignited, fired or otherwise set in action within the limits
of the City, any fireworks inconsistent with Illinois Compiled Statutes chapter
425, act 30, section 2.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to articles of the kind
and nature herein mentioned, which shall be in the possession of railroads or
transportation companies for the purpose of transportation, unless the same
shall be held voluntarily by such railroads or companies as warehousemen. This
chapter shall not apply to signal devices used by railroad companies or to
explosives used for blasting or similar purposes. (Ord. 19-O-10, 4-2-2019)
3-12-2: AUTHORITY OF FIRE DEPARTMENT CHIEF TO SEIZE OR REMOVE FIREWORKS:
The Chief of the Fire Department shall seize, take, remove or cause to be
removed, at the expense of the owner, all stocks or fireworks or combustibles
offered or exposed for sale, stored or held in violation of this chapter. (Ord.
19-O-10, 4-2-2019)
3-12-3: LICENSE REQUIRED FOR SEASONAL RETAILERS OF FIREWORKS:
Licenses for the seasonal retailers of fireworks by properly qualified
individuals or corporations may be issued by the Chief of the Fire Department
in such form as may be prescribed, and upon furnishing such information as the
Chief of the Fire Department may require. Such public sales by seasonal
retailers shall be of such character and so located, as in the opinion of the
Chief of the Fire Department, after proper inspection, shall not be hazardous
to property or endanger any person or persons. Application for such licenses
shall be made fifteen (15) days in advance of the first date of sale. (Ord. 19-
O-10, 4-2-2019)
3-12-4: STORAGE OF FIREWORKS BY SEASONAL RETAILERS; LICENSE REQUIRED:
Such fireworks or devices for public sale by seasonal retailers may be stored
within the limits of the City when the license for such storage has been issued
by the Chief of the Fire Department. The buildings or premises in or upon which
such storage is to be made shall be properly inspected by the Chief of the Fire
Department and certified as a proper place for such storage. No license shall
be issued for such storage within one hundred feet (100') of any inhabited
school, hospital, church or other public institution or any building used as a
place of public assembly. (Ord. 19-O-10, 4-2-2019)
3-12-5: LICENSE FEE:
The license fee for the public sale of fireworks by seasonal retailers shall be
two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for each site where the fireworks
are sold. (Ord. 19-O-10, 4-2-2019)
3-12-6: TERM OF LICENSE:
All licenses issued to seasonal retailers shall be valid for thirty (30) days
from the date the license is issued. The license will expire after thirty (30)
days of issuance. (Ord. 19-O-10, 4-2-2019)
3-12-7: PENALTY:
Notwithstanding any other remedies available to the City pursuant to this
chapter, any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
punished by a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for
each offense, to which court or adjudication costs may be added. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day on which the violation occurs or
continues to occur. (Ord. 19-O-10, 4-2-2019)
3-12-8: EXEMPT FROM REGULATION:
The fireworks display permits issued by the Fire Chief, pursuant to subsection
1-8B-7A17 of this Code, and the Assistant Fire Chief, pursuant to subsection
1-8B-8A29 of this Code, are excluded from regulation of this chapter. (Ord. 19-
O-10, 4-2-2019)

CHAPTER 2
NUISANCES
SECTION:

4-2-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to identify and deal with, within a timely
manner, certain public nuisances. (Ord. 87-O-41, 10-6-1987)
4-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
BULK WASTE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Appliances, including, but not limited to: washer, dryer, refrigerator,
freezer, stove, television, and water heater; or
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Indoor furniture, including, but not limited to: bed springs,
mattresses, carpet, couch, chairs, and cushions; or
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Other items exposed to the elements not designed for exterior use.
FRONT YARD: The yard extending across the full width of a lot that lies
adjacent to the public or private street or roads and extends from the front
property line of said lot to the front of the structure on the lot.
GARBAGE: The animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking and consumption of food.
JUNK: Scrap and old iron; steel, chain, brass, copper, magnesium, aluminum,
tin, lead or other base metals; scraps of woolens, clips, bagging, rubber and
glass and empty bottles of different kinds and sizes when the number of each
kind or size is less than one gross; wrecked or dilapidated motor vehicles;
engines; machinery stored or held; and all articles and things discarded or no
longer used as a manufactured article composed of or consisting of any one or
more of the materials or articles herein mentioned.
LANDSCAPE WASTE: All accumulations of grass or shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree
limbs and other materials accumulated as the result of the care of lawns,
shrubbery, vines and trees.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind.
PREMISES: Any real property or improvements thereon as the case may be.
PROPERTY: See definition of Premises.
RUBBISH: Combustible or noncombustible waste materials, except garbage, and the
term shall include the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other
combustible materials, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, excelsior, rubber,
leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral matter,
glass, crockery and dust and other similar materials.
WEEDS: Includes noxious weeds such as buckthorn, bull nettle, burdock, Canada
thistle, cocklebur, curled dock, dodders, field bindweed, giant foxtail, hoary
cress, jimson, Johnson grass, leafy spurge, oxeye daisy, perennial sow thistle,
quack grass, ragweed, Russian knapweed, sweet clover, wild carrot, wild garlic
and wild mustard. (Ord. 87-O-41, 10-6-1987; amd. Ord. 93-O-38, 7-20-1993; Ord.
11-O-47, 10-18-2011)
4-2-3: NUISANCES ENUMERATED:
It is hereby declared a public nuisance for any person owning, leasing,
occupying or having charge or possession of any premises in the city to
maintain such premises in such manner that any one or more of the following
subsections are found to exist:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Junk And Rubbish: The keeping, storage, depositing or accumulation on

however, that wood and building materials being used or to be used for a
project of construction or repair or renovation for which a building permit has
been obtained may be stored for such period of time as is necessary to
expeditiously complete the project.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Dirt, Sand, Gravel: The keeping, storage, depositing or accumulation of
dirt, sand, gravel, concrete or other similar materials for an unreasonable
period, which constitutes visual blight or reduces the aesthetic appearance of
the neighborhood or is offensive to the senses or is detrimental to nearby
property or property values. (Ord. 87-O-41, 10-6-1987)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Off Street Parking: The parking of motor vehicles in front yard of
premises except on parking lots built in conformance with title 10 of this
code.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Unified Development Code Violations: Any condition in violation of
title 10 of this code.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Building Codes Violations: Any condition in violation of title 9,
chapter 1, "Building Code"; title 9, chapter 2, "Residential Building Code";
title 9, chapter 4, "Plumbing Code"; or title 9, chapter 7, "Property
Maintenance Code", of this code.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Fire Code Violations: Any condition in violation of title 9, chapter 3,
"Fire Code", of this code. (Ord. 87-O-41, 10-6-1987; amd. 2006 Code)
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Weeds And Grass: Any premises or city right of way adjacent to that
premises on which the owner or person having control or the agent of the person
having control permits any grass or weeds over eight inches (8") in height or
deleterious, unhealthful growth or other noxious matter that may be growing,
lying or located thereon 1 . (Ord. 87-O-41, 10-6-1987)
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Bulk Waste: The keeping, storage, depositing or accumulation of bulk
waste. The keeping of bulk waste shall not be permitted on open porches,
carports, open garages, pavilions or similar structures.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Offensive Premises: Any premises which is not maintained so as to pose
a threat to the health, safety or welfare of the public, is littered with
animal feces, or which has improperly maintained trees, shrubs or vegetation

4-2-4: UNLAWFUL DUMPING OR DEPOSITING OF MATERIALS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Bodies Of Water: It is unlawful to dump or empty garbage, rubbish or
refuse of any kind, or the washings from any tank, truck, car or building, into
any running stream, swamp or pool or stagnant water within the city limits.

4-2-5: RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNER OR OCCUPANT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Every owner of real property within the city is required to maintain
such property in a manner so as not to violate the provisions of this chapter,
and such owner remains liable for violations hereof regardless of any contract
or agreement with any third party regarding such property.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Every occupant, lessee, or holder of any interest in property other

4-2-6: ABATEMENT NOTICE AND PROCEEDINGS:
The city shall cause the owner who violates subsections
4-2-3A, B, G, H and I of this chapter to abate such violation on his property.
If any owner fails to abate said violation on his property within ten (10) days
of notice by certified mail or personal service, the city may order the
abatement of the violation. The cost thereof shall be charged against the real
estate upon which the violation is located, and there shall be a lien upon said
real estate. In addition to the filing of a lien upon such real estate, the
city shall have authority to collect the cost by filing a personal collection
action against the owner in court. (Ord. 93-O-38, 7-20-1993)
4-2-7: LIEN PROVISIONS:
Charges for the cost incurred by the city for the abatement of a violation from
any property pursuant to this chapter shall be a lien upon the premises with
priority as provided in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-13, as amended.
At any time after a bill has been sent to the owner for abatement of the
violation, a lien may be filed with the recorder of deeds in the manner
provided by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-13, paragraph 1. The failure
of the city to record such lien claimed or to mail notice, or the failure of
the owner to receive notice of such lien shall not affect the right to
foreclose on the lien for those charges established in subsections A and B of
this section. For the purpose of this section, the city shall be deemed to
incur the cost of the abatement, as follows:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â If the abatement is done by city personnel, the cost transmitted by the
superintendent of the department which performs the abatement to the building
official, a calculation of the number of hours required to do the abatement by
those employees times the hourly wage of said employees (including cost of
benefits of employment per hour), the fair market rental of all pieces of
equipment necessary to perform the abatement, plus the cost of disposal of all
materials removed.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the abatement is done by private contractor, the amount said
contractor invoices the city for work, plus disposal of materials removed.
(Ord. 93-O-38, 7-20-1993)
4-2-8: INSPECTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In order to safeguard the safety, health and welfare of the public, the
duly authorized agent of the city is authorized to access any property at any
reasonable time for the purpose of making inspections and performing duties
under this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If any owner, occupant, or other person in charge of a structure or
premises subject to the provisions of this chapter refuses, impedes, inhibits,
interferes with, restricts or obstructs entry and free access to any part of
the structure or premises where inspection authorized by this chapter is
sought, the city shall seek, in a court of competent jurisdiction, an order
that such owner, occupant, or other person in charge shall permit an inspection
of his premises. (Ord. 93-O-38, 7-20-1993)
4-2-9: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Citation: Any violation of this chapter will, unless otherwise
specified, result in the issuance of a complaint or citation for an ordinance
violation by a police officer, the fire chief or his designee, or the building
official or his designee.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be
subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor greater
than five hundred dollars ($500.00). A separate offense may be deemed committed
on each day during or on which violation occurs or continues.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Temporary Restraining Order: In any action or proceedings brought
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, the circuit court shall have the
power and, in its discretion, may issue a temporary restraining order or a
temporary injunction, as well as a permanent injunction, upon such terms and
under such conditions as will do justice and enforce the provisions of this
chapter.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Other Remedies: In addition to the foregoing, the city shall have such
other powers to abate nuisances as may be provided by law. (Ord. 93-O-38, 7-20-

CHAPTER 3
GARBAGE AND RUBBISH COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL
SECTION:
4-3-1: Definitions
4-3-2: Receptacles
4-3-3: Reserved
4-3-4: Disposal Of Garbage, Rubbish And Landscape Waste
4-3-5: Violations; Penalties
4-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, when used in this chapter, have the meanings respectively
ascribed to them in this section:
GARBAGE: Animal or vegetable waste from food supply and food supply cans,
including only such paper in which it may be wrapped.
LANDSCAPE WASTE: All accumulations of grass or shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree
limbs and other materials accumulated as the result of the care of lawns,
shrubbery, vines and trees.
RUBBISH: Combustible and noncombustible waste materials, except garbage, and
the term shall include the residue from the burning of wood, coal and coke, and
other combustible materials, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, excelsior,
rubber, leather, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, crockery, dust and
similar materials. "Rubbish" does not include tires, batteries, hazardous
substances and other regulated items disallowed for disposal in the landfill.
(Ord. 99-O-35, 7-20-1999)
4-3-2: RECEPTACLES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Required: Every owner, or his agent, or the occupant of any house,
building or apartment in the City wherein persons reside, board or lodge shall
provide for each such house, building or apartment and at all times maintain in
good order and repair, containers for garbage, rubbish and combustible
materials, in a number sufficient to store and to handle for disposal the
accumulations for each such house, building and apartment according to the
specifications in subsection B of this section.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Specifications:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Garbage:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â For garbage, all properties with curbside service shall use a
"tote" container or other garbage storage container approved by the City. For
garbage, all properties with backyard service shall either use a "tote"
container approved by the City and provided by the hauler, or provide their own
containers.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â All garbage containers shall be watertight, made of metal,
plastic, or other suitable material to be approved by the City and have a close
fitting cover in order that animals be unable to force the lid open.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The name of the garbage hauler shall be denoted on all garbage
containers used for curbside service and shall be readily visible and obvious
for easy identification. The hauler shall provide the appropriate emblem 1 .
The containers shall have a capacity of not less than twenty (20) gallons and
not more than forty (40) gallons, and shall be fitted with suitable handles
unless it is a "tote" type of container provided by a licensed collector.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Rubbish And Landscape Waste: For rubbish and landscape waste, the
size and type of containers shall be identical to the containers used for
garbage; except, that plastic bags may be used.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Placement For Collection: For curbside collection, containers and totes
shall be placed at the curb no earlier than seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. the day
before the scheduled collection by a licensed hauler, and shall be removed from
the curb no later than seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. the day of scheduled
collection. Should the hauler fail to collect items on the scheduled day, the
owner/agent/occupant of the property must remove the items from the curb by the
prescribed time above. Items too large for containers (furniture, appliances,
landscape waste, etc.) shall not be placed at the curb and shall be concealed
from sight at all times until collected. Arrangement for the timely removal of
such items shall be the responsibility of the owner/agent/occupant.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Maintenance Of Receptacle Area: The garbage collector is responsible
for cleaning up only that garbage, rubbish and landscape waste which is
scattered in the process of conveying the material to his truck. It is the sole
responsibility of the customer to clean up any garbage, rubbish and landscape
waste which is strewn about from the ravages of animals or other causes.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Screening Requirements:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Owners/agents/occupants with backyard collection shall conceal or
screen all containers and large items from sight at all times.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Owners/agents/occupants with curbside collection shall conceal or
screen all containers and large items from sight at all times; except, that
containers, only, may be placed at the curb during the time prescribed in this
chapter.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Open Containers Restricted:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Rubbish and landscape waste may be placed in open containers or
plastic bags as long as there is no danger of the contents being blown about by
the wind or improperly discharged in any manner. Failure to properly store
rubbish and landscape waste shall be unlawful.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The use of open containers for food cans, cartons or any other
material which will draw flies is strictly unlawful. Such containers must be
tightly covered in metal or plastic cans which have the same specifications as
garbage cans. (Ord. 99-O-35, 7-20-1999)

Applications for scavenger licenses shall be made to the clerk and shall be

No scavenger license shall be issued unless and until the applicant therefor

This bond shall be conditioned to indemnify the city for any damage, loss or
liability resulting from the conduct of business by the licensee and shall also
be conditioned that the licensee shall obey all the ordinances relating to the
business conducted in the city. (Ord. 99-O-34, 7-20-1999)

CHAPTER 4
NEW OR EXPANDED POLLUTION CONTROL FACILITY SITES
SECTION:
4-4-1: Definitions
4-4-2: Notice Of Intent For Site Approval
4-4-3: Application For Site Approval
4-4-4: Public Hearings
4-4-5: City Council Approval
4-4-6: Application Fees
4-4-7: Host Agreement
4-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
AGENCY: Illinois environmental protection agency.
BOARD: Illinois pollution control board.
POLLUTION CONTROL FACILITIES: Any waste storage, sanitary landfill, waste
disposal site, waste transfer station, waste treatment facility, or waste
incinerator which wishes to be located within the corporate limits of the city
of Charleston, or the expansion of any existing facility described herein
within the corporate limits of the city of Charleston. (Ord. 96-O-13, 3-5-1996)
4-4-2: NOTICE OF INTENT FOR SITE APPROVAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â At least fourteen (14) days prior to filing a pollution control
facility application with the city, the applicant shall notify in written form,
either in person or by registered mail (return receipt requested), the
following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â All owners of all property within the subject area not totally owned
by the applicant.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â All owners identified through tax records of Coles County, a
property within two hundred fifty feet (250') in each direction of a lot line
of the subject property. In computing the two hundred fifty foot (250')
requirement, all property occupied by public roads, streets, alleys or other
public ways should be excluded. In no event shall this requirement exceed four
hundred feet (400'), including public streets, alleys or other public ways.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Members of the general assembly from the legislative district from
which the proposed facility will be located.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â At least fourteen (14) days prior to filing an application with the
city, notice shall be published in the newspaper having the largest general
circulation in the city. Such notices shall state: 1) name and address of the
applicant; 2) location of the proposed site; 3) the nature and size of the
development; 4) the nature of the activity proposed; 5) the probable life of
the activity; 6) the date when the request for site approval will be submitted
to the city; 7) a description of the right of persons to comment on such
request. (Ord. 96-O-13, 3-5-1996)
4-4-3: APPLICATION FOR SITE APPROVAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The applicant shall file in the office of the city clerk, twenty five
(25) copies of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â An application form provided by the city and available in the city
clerk's office.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Information and documentation requested on a form provided by the
city and which is available in the city clerk's office which supports the
application based on the criteria as established by 415 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/39.2.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Copies of all documents submitted to the Illinois environmental
protection agency in connection with the application to the Illinois
environmental protection agency permitted for citing approval, except trade
secrets as determined in 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/17.1.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Upon receipt of any such request, the city clerk shall date- stamp the
same and immediately deliver the request to the mayor and building official.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â No application for site approval shall be deemed to have been filed or
accepted for filing unless all the required attachments have been included. In
order to prove that all attachments have been submitted, the building official
shall review the request to determine if the application is complete. The
intent of this review is to minimize delays that may be caused by an incomplete
application. If complete, the application shall be considered to be filed as of
the date it was deemed as being complete by the building official.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Within twenty (20) working days of the receipt of the request, the
building official shall notify the applicant and the city clerk:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â That the application is complete and is accepted for filing; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â That the application is not complete, specifying the
deficiencies. Should the application be deemed incomplete, it is considered not
filed and is not subject to further action being taken.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â If the application is complete, the city clerk shall, within five
(5) working days of the notice that the application is complete, forward one
set of the request and all attachments to: a) city council members; b) city
attorney; c) city engineer; d) Coles County health department; e) fire chief of
the city; f) general assembly members from the legislative districts affected.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â All such documents shall be placed in a file in the office of the city
clerk and shall be available for public inspection and may be copied upon
payment of actual costs of reproduction.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Any person may file written comments about the application with the
city clerk. The city council shall consider any comments that are received
postmarked no later than thirty (30) days after date of the last public
hearing.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â The city clerk shall date-stamp the written comment and immediately
forward one copy to each of the persons/agencies outlined in subsection B of
this section. The city clerk will note the date of the postmark on the envelope
in receiving the copy. (Ord. 96-O-13, 3-5-1996)
4-4-4: PUBLIC HEARINGS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Public forum public hearings shall be held by the city council no
sooner than ninety (90) days but no later than one hundred twenty (120) days
from receipt of the application for site approval.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Within sixty (60) days of receipt of the application, the mayor shall
notify the applicant, in writing, of the scheduled public hearing date.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The applicant shall be responsible for publishing notice of the public
hearing in the newspaper of largest general circulation in Coles County. The
applicant shall also notify, by certified mail, all members of the general
assembly from the district in which the proposed site is located, and the
Illinois environmental protection agency.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The public hearing shall develop a record sufficient to form the basis
of appeal of the decision in accordance with 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
40.1.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The mayor shall preside over the public hearing. The hearing officers
shall consist of the city council. The mayor may request that the
representatives of the city attorney's office, the city planning and zoning
department, and the city engineer be present at the hearing to assist the
hearing officers.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The hearing officers, based upon the application, written comments,
transcripts of public hearings and other pertinent documents shall determine
compliance or noncompliance with the review criteria and make recommendations
on site approval to the city council no sooner than thirty (30) days after the
last public hearing but no later than sixty (60) days after the last public
hearing.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Any time prior to the completion by the applicant of the present
application, and the hearing of factual evidence and the cross questioning by
the city council and the participants, the applicant may not file more than one
amended application upon payment of additional fees pursuant to section
4-4-6 of this chapter in which an additional period of ninety (90) days is
required. (Ord. 96-O-13, 3-5-1996)
4-4-5: CITY COUNCIL APPROVAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No sooner than thirty (30) days after the last public hearing but no
later than one hundred eighty (180) days from receipt of the application for
site approval, the city council shall, at a regular or special meeting, approve
or deny the application for a new pollution control facility site.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â After reviewing the recommendation of the hearing officers, the city
council shall base its decision on the application for a new regional pollution
control facility in accordance with 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/39.2, as
follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The facility is necessary to accommodate the waste needs of the
city.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The facility is so designed, located and proposed to be operated so
the public health, safety and welfare shall be protected.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The facility is located so as to minimize incompatibility with the
character of the surrounding area and to minimize the effect on the value of
the surrounding property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The facility must be located outside the boundary of the 100-year
floodplain or the site of a flood.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The plan of operations for the facility is designed to minimize the
danger surrounding the area from fire, spills, or other operational accidents.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Traffic patterns to and from the facility are so designed as to
minimize the impact on existing traffic flows.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â If the facility will be treating and disposing of hazardous waste,
an emergency response plan must exist for the facility which includes
notification, containment and evacuation procedures to be used in case of an
accidental release.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â The city council may consider the evidence of previous operating
experience and the past record of convictions or admissions of past violations
of the applicant, and any subsidiary or parent corporation in the field of
solid waste management.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The statement of the decision and reason for the decision based on the
criteria and conditions imposed by the city council shall be made in writing.
The Illinois environmental protection agency and the applicant shall be
notified by registered mail of the decision.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The city council's root decision shall be made available for public
inspection at the office of the city clerk and copies provided upon payment of
the actual cost of reproduction.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â If there is no final action by the city council within one hundred
eighty (180) days of filing of the application for site approval, the applicant
may deem the request approved. (Ord. 96-O-13, 3-5-1996)
4-4-6: APPLICATION FEES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No new pollution control application will be accepted until a filing
fee is paid.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The following application fee shall be made payable to the city of
Charleston and shall be paid to the city clerk's office:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Applications for waste storage sites waste transfer stations shall
pay a fee of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Landfills with disposal sites with treatment or waste facility or
waste incinerator shall pay a fee of two hundred thousand dollars
($200,000.00).
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The applicant shall be responsible for any costs that may be incurred
upon the application fee during the application process. The additional costs
incurred within the application process exceeding the application fee shall be
submitted by the applicant for payment as they occur. Further, for any
unprojected costs above the application fee, the council has the right to
request payment for said costs. Said costs will be paid by the applicant within
thirty (30) days of request by the city.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Fees collected hereunder shall be used only to defray costs incurred by
the city in connection with site approval application which may include
professional consultants hired by the city to provide technical assistance. Any
remainder after final resolution shall be refunded to the applicant. (Ord. 96-
O-13, 3-5-1996)
4-4-7: HOST AGREEMENT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Prior to final city council approval for the pollution control
facility, the applicant shall negotiate with the city a host agreement.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The host agreement shall regulate the type of facility to be run, host
fee payments, capacity guarantees to the city, and requirements for transfer of
ownership or lease to another corporation or individual of the facility.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â All host fee payments shall be negotiated as per the Illinois solid
waste management act 1  which authorizes local government entities to collect a
surcharge from pollution control facilities. (Ord. 96-O-13, 3-5-1996)

CHAPTER 5
TREES
SECTION:
4-5-1: Title
4-5-2: Definitions
4-5-3: Duties Of Property Owners
4-5-4: Violation; Penalty
4-5-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the TREE ORDINANCE FOR THE CITY
OF CHARLESTON. (Ord. 69-O-17, 7-15-1969)
4-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their
derivations shall have the meanings given in this section:
CITY: The city of Charleston, Coles County, Illinois.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind.
TREE: A tree in a public place except where otherwise indicated. (Ord. 69-O-17,
7-15-1969)
4-5-3: DUTIES OF PROPERTY OWNERS:
It shall be the duty of any person growing trees, plants or bushes within a
public highway or property abutting on public places or property:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â To trim his trees, plants or bushes so as not to cause a hazard to
public places or interfere with the proper lighting of public highways by the
streetlights, or interfere with the free flow of traffic along the public way,
or obstruct the view of motorists using the public way, and so that the minimum
clearance of any overhanging portion of any tree shall be nine feet (9').
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â To treat or remove any tree or plant so diseased or insect ridden as to
constitute a hazard to trees or plants in public places. (Ord. 69-O-17, 7-15-
1969)
4-5-4: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an
amount not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00). Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall
constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. (Ord.
69-O-17, 7-15-1969)
CHAPTER 6
GRASS AND WEEDS
SECTION:
4-6-1: Weeds And Other Matter
4-6-2: Notice To Destroy
4-6-3: Action Upon Noncompliance
4-6-4: Notice Of Lien
4-6-5: Penalty For Violation
4-6-6: Foreclosure Of Liens
4-6-1: WEEDS AND OTHER MATTER 1 :
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Controlled: Except as provided in subsection B of this section, no
owner and no person in control of any lot, place or area within the city and no
agent of such owner or person in control, shall permit on such lot, place or
area or upon any abutting area between the right of way line/property line and
street surface or pavement, any weeds or grass over eight inches (8") in
height, or deleterious, unhealthful growths or other noxious matter that may be
growing, lying, or located thereon.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Exemptions: The following are generally exempted from the provisions of
this chapter:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Lands zoned agricultural as designated in title 10 of this code and
shown on the official zoning map of the city unless used for nonagricultural
purposes. For purposes of this subsection "agricultural use" shall be construed
to mean vacant land or the production of products such as field crops,
livestock, fowl and other conventional agricultural pursuits; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Lands in any zoning district(s), which are being used for
agricultural purposes.
Provided, however, that the portions of those lands exempted by this subsection
which are within twenty feet (20') of the right of way of a public street or
alley maintained for traffic or within twenty feet (20') of the property line
of adjacent lands used for nonagricultural or nonforestry purposes (for
example, church, school, store, factory, house, apartment building, offices,
etc.) shall not be exempted from the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 08-O-19,
7-15-2008)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  4-2-3G of this title.
4-6-2: NOTICE TO DESTROY:
The city manager, or his designee, annually, at or near the commencement of the
growth season, shall notify, by general publication in a newspaper published
within the city, all such owners, person in control, or agents, to cut,
destroy, or remove any such weeds, grass, growths, or matter found growing,
lying or located on such properties and areas regulated by section
4-6-1 of this chapter. (Ord. 08-O-19, 7-15-2008)
4-6-3: ACTION UPON NONCOMPLIANCE:
Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any such owner, person in control or
agent so notified to cut, destroy or remove such weeds, grass, growths or
matter, after publication of the notice provided for in section
4-6-2 of this chapter, the city or its authorized agent shall cut, destroy or
remove such weeds, grass, growth or matter, and any expense incurred by the
city or its authorized agent in so doing shall be a charge against the owner,
person in control or agent so failing, which charge may be recovered in an
appropriate action at law; provided, however, that no land clearance made
necessary by excessive growth shall be done unless the city or its authorized
agent shall first post a notice on such property to clear such excessive
growth, and such owner, person in control or agent shall fail for seven (7)
days after such notice to so clear such land. In addition to reimbursement of
costs incurred by the city, handling fee(s) and/or late fee(s) may be imposed
as determined by the city. (Ord. 11-O-23, 5-3-2011)
4-6-4: NOTICE OF LIEN:
If such weeds, grass, growth or matter are cut, destroyed or removed by this
city or its agent, a notice of lien of the cost and expense thereof incurred
shall be recorded in the following manner: The city or its agent shall file
notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds of Coles County,
Illinois. Such notice of lien shall contain a description of the real estate
sufficient for identification thereof, the amount of money representing the
cost and expense incurred or payable for the service, and the date or dates
when said costs and expense were incurred. Such notice shall be under oath and
shall be filed within sixty (60) days after the cost and expense is incurred.
Such liens are assessed to recover the expenses incurred by the city and shall
not serve as an exemption from any penalties imposed for violation of this
chapter. (Ord. 08-O-19, 7-15-2008)
4-6-5: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
Any owner, person in control, or agent who does not maintain property subject
to section
4-6-1 of this chapter in compliance with the provisions of said section
4-6-1 of this chapter, shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than
ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each
day such a violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a
separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. (Ord. 08-O-19, 7-
15-2008)
4-6-6: FORECLOSURE OF LIENS:
In addition to any other legal remedy available under this code or applicable
state or federal law, any lien filed pursuant to this chapter may be enforced
by proceedings to foreclose, as in the case of mortgage or mechanic's liens
under Illinois law, against the property subject to said lien for the
collection of weed cutting costs incurred by the city plus any and all
administrative, filing and/or legal fees or costs for the enforcement of the
provisions under this chapter or such unpaid liens may be sent to the Coles
County clerk for collection through property tax billing as allowed under
Illinois law. Such action shall be commenced only upon those liens which equal
or exceed a total amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) collectively
against a parcel of property (i.e., 1 or more weed liens filed on the same
property for weed cutting costs, including administrative, filing and legal
fees) and has been recorded in the Coles County recorder's office for a one
year period or longer. (Ord. 08-O-19, 7-15-2008)

CHAPTER 1

SECTION:

5-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless the text otherwise indicates, the following
terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
AT LARGE: A. On the premises of person other than owner, possessor or keeper
without consent.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In or upon a vehicle without consent of the vehicle owner.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In a park, public or private school grounds or public place whatsoever
and not under the owner's control by leash or other means of physical
restraint.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â On a public way, except when under the owner's control by a leash.
DOG: Both male and female dogs.
DOMESTIC ANIMALS: Any animal located within the city of Charleston used as a
pet and not for livestock purposes.
OWNER: Any person or persons, firm, association or corporation owning, keeping,
or harboring a domestic animal. (Ord. 69-O-21, 8-6-1969, eff. 8-16-1969; amd.
Ord. 94-O-42, 9-6-1994)
5-1-2: LICENSE, COMPLIANCE AND TAG REQUIRED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â License And Compliance Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to
own, possess or harbor a domestic animal without first having obtained a
license therefor in compliance with the ordinances made and providing for same
by the county. (Ord. 75-O-10, 2-4-1975; amd. Ord. 94-O-42, 9-6-1994)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Tag: Every domestic animal over the age of six (6) months, whether
kennel licensed or individually licensed, and if individually licensed, whether
on or off the owner's premises, shall at all times wear a substantial, durable
collar, to which shall be attached securely, the license tag required; further,
said tag shall not be used on the collar of any other domestic animal than the
one for which it is issued; and further, no person shall remove the collar or
tag, or both, from any domestic animal without the consent of the person to
whom the license is issued. (Ord. 58-O-5, 5-28-1958; amd. Ord. 94-O-42, 9-6-
1994)
5-1-3: RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED:
No domestic animal, whether licensed or unlicensed, muzzled or unmuzzled, shall
be allowed to run at large. If any such domestic animal is found running at
large in violation of this section, it shall be taken up and impounded by the
animal control warden, and shall not be released except upon approval of said
warden and payment of the appropriate fees. (Ord. 69-O-21, 8-6-1969; amd. 1991
Code; Ord. 94-O-42, 9-6-1994)
5-1-4: RABIES CONTROL:
If a domestic animal is believed to have rabies or is bitten by a domestic
animal suspected of having rabies, the procedures shall be followed as set out
by the county animal control regulations and state statute provisions in 510
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12, 5/13 and 5/14. (1991 Code; amd. Ord. 94-O-42,
9-6-1994)
5-1-5: PROHIBITED CONDITIONS:
It shall also be unlawful for any person to do any of the following acts:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Noise: To keep or harbor or own any domestic animal which shall, by
loud or frequent or habitual barking, yelping or howling, cause annoyance to
the neighborhood or to people passing to and fro on the streets.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Dangerous, Threatening Animal: To keep or harbor or own any domestic
animal which, by constant threat of attacking or biting, shall cause annoyance
to the neighborhood or to people passing to and fro on the streets.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Failure To Take Animal To Pound: To refuse to deliver up his domestic
animal or domestic animals to the county animal shelter when properly requested
to do so.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Cruelty: For any person keeping, harboring or owning a domestic animal
or any other person to be cruel and inhumane to a domestic animal, said
treatment to consist of cruelty, beating, torturing, mutilating, cruelly
killing, failure to provide food, drink or shelter or abandoning any domestic
animal. (Ord. 69-O-21, 8-15-1969, eff. 8-25-1969; amd. Ord. 94-O-42, 9-6-1994)
5-1-6: EXCREMENT REMOVAL REQUIRED:
Every owner or person having possession and/or control of any dog or any other
animal shall be required to immediately remove and appropriately dispose of any
and all animal defecation that has been placed upon private property or public
property within the city by the animal under said person's ownership, custody
and/or possession, except for private property owned or under the control of
the individual owning or in possession of the animal. (Ord. 99-O-1, 1-5-1999)
5-1-7: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any owner found violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not
less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 69-O-21, 8-15-1969, eff. 8-25-1969; amd. Ord.
99-O-1, 1-5-1999)
